title: south western railway strikes five day walkouts london uk today
story: South Western Railway passengers heading into the capital from Surrey, Hampshire, Berkshire, Dorset, Somerset and Devon will be met with reduced services from this morning.The strikes are expected to be the longest in the two year dispute over the future of the role of guards on trains and come as the half-term break begins this week.About two thirds of normal weekday services are expected to run on SWR this week.There will be no South Western Railway service from Exeter to Yeovil and passengers have been advised there will be rail placement buses available.Meanwhile, there will be no SWR service – or replacement bus service - from Bristol towards London from today.Services will be disrupted following the RMT’s decision to strike between Tuesday and Saturday following the ongoing dispute regarding the role of guards on trains.Other routes operating on a reduced service into London Waterloo include trains from Weymouth, Southampton, Portsmouth, Basingstoke, Woking, Epsom and Reading.SWR urged the RMT to call off the strikes and has hit out at the union for “cynically targeting hard-working commuters, families and sports fans”.A SWR spokesman said: “The RMT is cynically targeting hard-working commuters, families trying to enjoy the half-term holidays and sports fans with its latest strike dates.Southampton - London WaterlooPortsmouth - London WaterlooAlton - London WaterlooDorking - London WaterlooYeovil - London WaterlooReading - London WaterlooBristol - London WaterlooExeter - London Waterloo “We have guaranteed a guard to be rostered on every single service, and our growth plans mean more guards, not fewer. It is time for the union to stop spreading myths and causing misery to our customers and colleagues, and commit to resolving this dispute.“If the union decides to continue with its unnecessary action, we will do everything we can to keep our customers moving and reduce disruption.”But the RMT hit back and Mick Cash, RMT General Secretary, accused SWR of “stalling the talks process”.He said: “South Western Railway has stalled the talks process and has failed to provide any sort of offer that comes close to resolving this dispute which matches the widespread best practice in the industry, underpinned by the guard guarantee.With shocking new figures from the British Transport Police showing a surge in violence on our railways it is frankly appalling that South Western Railway are looking for a green light to throw the guard off their trains as and when they see fit in the name of profit.It comes as rail passengers in Scotland are facing major disruptions this morning after engineering works overran near Glasgow Queen Street.No trains are running out of the high-level station, which is affecting services to Edinburgh and Aberdeen.Network Rail said a piece of machinery broke down shortly before am on Tuesday and they are working to remove it.ScotRail said it was working to secure replacement buses and stressed that low-level services to Edinburgh were not affected.A Network Rail spokesman said: Overnight, Network Rail engineers were carrying out work to the track and overhead line equipment at Cowlais.Shortly before ., a piece of machinery broke down. Network Rail workers are currently working to remove the failed equipment.Due to the nature of the incident, no trains are currently able to run from the high-level s at Glasgow Queen Street railway station.Passengers are urged to check before they travel via National Rail Enquiries or with their train operator.Wed like to apologise for any disruption this incident is causing and thank passengers for their patience.

title: greek odysseus trading vessel 2400 years found intact black sea
story: The ancient Greek trading ship was found whole, bow to stern, with even its mast, rudders and rowing benches almost perfectly preserved.The ship looks almost identical to a vessel shown on a vase in the British Museum depicting Greek hero Odysseus voyage home from the Trojan war.Scientists at the Black Sea Maritime Archaeology Project determined the  foot vessel was consigned to Davy Jones’ Locker more than , years ago.It was found in what has been described as a “shipwreck graveyard” where over  other sunken ships have been discovered.The ship was found in  by a remote controlled submarine piloted by Brit scientists but has just been confirmed as the “oldest intact shipwreck”.It has the design of an Ancient Greek trading vessel design previously only seen on the side of ancient Greek pottery such as the “Siren Vase” in the British Museum.The ship is over . miles deep on the bed of the Black Sea where the water is oxygen free, around  miles off the coast of Bulgaria.This “anoxic” water can preserve organic material for millennia and a small piece of the vessel has been carbon dated to BC.It revealed the accuracy of the painter of the Siren Vase who painted an almost identical vessel onto the pottery.Jon Adams, professor of archaeology at the University of Southampton and chief scientist of the team that found the wreck, told The Times: “Nobody has ever known how accurate the representation on the Siren Vase was and whether the artist was making it up or drawing what he saw.“Now we see archaeological evidence showing a ship very close in detail, even down to the shape of the rudder blade.“The artist must have been familiar with ships.”Prior to this discovery ancient ships had only been found in fragments with the oldest more than , years old.The team from the Black Sea Maritime Archaeological Project said the find also revealed how far from the shore ancient Greek traders could travel.Archaeologist believes it probably held - men at the time whose remains may be hidden in the surrounding sediment or eaten by bacteria.He said he plans to leave the ship on the seabed because raising it would be hugely expensive and require taking some of the joints apart.The ship, which was powered by both sails and oars was mainly used for trade but could have occasionally played a role in battle, raiding coastal cities.The find is one of  wrecks found in the area.Previous finds were discovered dating back as far as , years, including galleys from the Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman empires.The design on the ancient property depicts a scene from Homer’s Odyssey, one of the oldest and most famous stories in history.It details the tale of Odysseus and his ten year journey back from fighting in the Trojan War.On the epic voyage he encounters numerous mythological figures including a Cyclops, gods and goddesses and even a visit to the underworld.But one of the most famous scenes, as depicted on the vase, involves the eponymous hero ordering his crew to lash him to lash him to the mast and block his ears to resist the “Siren’s call”Sirens were dangerous creatures who would lure sailors to shipwreck on the rock coasts with their enchanting songs.They were said to be a combination of women and birds.

title: prince harrry response wrap up talk widow australia tour
story: The Duke of Sussex, , was told by his staff to wrap up his chat with Gwen Cherne, , at Sydney Harbour Bridge during his first royal tour with we Meghan.However, the widow revealed that Harry said he was “in the middle of a conversation” and continued his emotional talk with grieving Gwen on Friday, reports People.She said: “He stopped and said, Im in a middle of a conversation, and Im not going to leave this.We were talking about my story and mental health and how dficult it is still, in our society, to talk about grief and loss and suicide.”The pair even shared a hug together after their heartfelt chat.Gwen, who was part of a group climbing the famous bridge in Sydney with Harry, lost her husband Peter J. Café after he tragically took his own le.Peter was an Australian special forces officer who served in Cambodia, Afghanistan and Iraq.She is now an ambassador for the Invictus and War Widows Guild following her beloved husband’s death.Created by Harry, the Invictus Games are an international Paralympic-style sporting event for wounded, sick or injured members of the armed forces, as well as veterans.Gwen said she and Harry also discussed how important the event was at “shedding light” on issues such as mental health and “allowing people to start to have these conversations that are great to have.The prince also climbed the bridge with Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison and a group of former veterans turned elite athletes.Harry and Meghan’s royal tour coincides with the fourth Invictus Games which are taking place in Australia’s largest city.The Duke has expressed his personal joy over his wes pregnancy in a moving speech at the sporting events opening ceremony at the Sydney Opera House on Saturday.Prince Harry, who was attending the ceremony with Meghan, said: First of all, thank you for the welcome you have given Meghan and I over the last few days.I have been so proud to be able to introduce my we to you and we have been so happy to be able to celebrate the personal joy of our newest addition with you all.

title: asda manuka honey facebook
story: A photo that was shared on Facebook shows the bright green security tags on the Rowse Manuka honey, which is selling for a dear £..Shoppers were quick to mock the supermarket over their security measures and the price it was charging.Beth Peterson took the photo and shared it while she was shopping in Asda last night in South Shields, County Durham.She added the caption: “I’ve never laughed so hard in my le!!“I know it’s stupid for laughing, but found it funny that there is a security tag on hunny.”Beth told The Sun Online she was surprised to see the jars of Manuka honey on the shelf with the security tags on it.She said: “I was Hysterical laughing, I couldn’t believe that I had just saw a honey jar with a security tag on it “What’s going to be next  Cheese ”She said she was shocked at the price.She said: “I couldn’t believe the price either, I nearly fell through the floor!”Beth, of South Shields, shared the photo to cheer people up.She said: “I just took the pic as it was funny and I thought it could brighten up someone’s day.”Many were quick to comment on the price of the honey.One person commented : “I’m always flabbergasted that people will pay THAT much for honey.”Another added: Its the size of the security tag thats the funniest.Manuka honey is exported from New Zealand and is said to contain antibacterial properties, which contribute to its high price.It is commonly sold as an alternative medicine, despite no conclusive evidence that it has medicinal value.However, that still hasn’t won some over.One said: “health benefits or not.. I wouldn’t be seen spending £ on a jar of bee sick.”An Asda spokeswoman said Manuka honey will always have a security tag because of its retail price.

title: granddad sepsis nail biting
story: Ricky Kennedy from Dumbarton, Scotland, contracted the infection after nibbling down on his thumbnail in January this year.Within hours, the infection spread from his thumb to his arms and chest, resulting in him being hospitalised a couple of days later.The -year-old was only given a  per cent chance of surviving the ordeal, and had to spend months in a hospital bed.The deadly sepsis infection has left him with an eroded collarbone, asthma and septic arthritis.Speaking to the Daily Record, he said: “I’m lucky to be alive. I may never be as healthy or strong as I was but I’m still here with my family and that is very precious to me.”The grandad, who also suffers from type  diabetes, fell ill in January , with the blood poisoning taking hold of his body within hours.Ricky claims that he had bitten his thumbnail down too far, and noticed a tiny blister forming on his thumb.Thinking nothing of it, he initially ignored it but a few hours later, the infection has spread through his blood stream.He added: “All I can remember is asking a nurseI was going to die. It was a terrible time.”Sepsis is the primary cause of death from infection around the world, claiming around , lives in the UK each year – that’s more than more deaths than bowel, breast and prostate cancer combined.The condition is always triggered by an infection.Most often the culprit is an infection we all recognise - pneumonia, urinary infections , skin infections, including cellulitis, and infections in the stomach, for example appendicitis.Typically, when a person suffers a minor cut, the area surrounding the wound will become red, swollen and warm to touch.This is evidence the bodys immune system has kicked into action, releasing white blood cells to the site of the injury to kill off the bacteria causing the infection.The white blood cells and platelets form blood clots in the tissues around the cut.Blood vessels swell to allow more blood to flow, and they become leaky, allowing infection-fighting cells to get out of the blood and into the tissues where they are needed.This causes inflammation, which appears to us as the red, warm swelling.When sepsis happens, this system goes into overdrive.The inflammation that is typically seen just around the minor cut, spreads through the body, affecting healthy tissue and organs.The immune system - the bodys defence mechanism - overreacts and the result is it attacks the body.It can lead to organ failure and septic shock, which can prove fatal.

title: meghan markle holds baby bump prince harry fiji banquet
story: The royal couple dressed up to the nines for the black tie dinner hosted by the country’s president at the Grand Pacic Hotel.The Duke of Sussex wore a tuxedo while the Duchess came decked out in a light blue dress by designer SAFiYAA.The gorgeous gown features a cape silhouette and the colour is thought to be a nod to the host country, whose flag is the same shade.The outfit, worn with diamond drop-earrings and her hair down, was by German-born London-based designer Daniela Karmuts.The pair smiled as they chatted with other guests at the champagne reception ahead of the banquet.Meghan earlier arrived in Fiji wearing a dress by Australian designer Zimmerman, a hat by Stephen Jones, earrings given to her by the Queen and a bracelet which was a gt from the Prince of Wales.The pair were met at Suvas Nausori Airport by Melanie Hopkins, the High Commissioner and chief of protocol, Jonetani Tagivetaua.They disembarked their Qantas charter flight to light rain and were introduced to the Hon Frank Bainamara, Fijis PM and his we, Maria, Ro Teimumu Kepa.But everything didnt go quite as smoothly as they might have liked, with winds blowing the Duchesss hair across her face.The red carpet even came close to taking off amid the strong gusts - but the royal couple appeared to laugh it off.The Duchess was presented with a bouquet of flowers by a girl from the chiefly island of Bau, before Harry made his way to a dais on the runway.Bau is the home of Ratu Apensia Cakobau, who ceded Fiji to Britain in .Harry and Meghan observed a royal salute, and the Duke was then invited to inspect the guard of honour.The royal couple then left for their next engagement - a meeting with Fijis President, Jioji Konrote - before heading to an official welcome ceremony.The event took place at Albert Park, and mirrored the Queen and Duke of Edinburghs visit in .Harry and Meghan were met by dozens of men in traditional garb, who performed a welcome dance and presented them with an entire roasted pig.The Prince was also given a cup of traditional drink Kava, knocking it back and shouting Bula!The word is a greeting and its expected that he shout it as part of the ceremony.The pair will spend four days in the South Pacic travelling on to Tonga later in the week.Mum-to-be Meghan was back on official royal tour duty today after taking a break from official engagements.Harry had attended three of yesterdays events on his own, including an unveiling of the Queens Commonwealth Canopy, where he joked about plaque-unveiling running in the family.Harry had told his pregnant we to take it easy as the couple carry out a -day tour across Australia, New Zealand, Fiji and Tonga.A royal aide said: She isnt sick, she just had a tiring few days.And we were concerned about the roads on the island which are incredibly bumpy and uncomfortable for anyone, let alone a pregnant woman.But the duchess was very keen to re-join the duke at the last engagement of the day to greet the people of the island.As they left Australia, the couple were driven to Hervey Bay Airport, where Megan wore a loose fitting white shirt and black trousers.Harry opted for a black shirt and chinos as they waved to a crowd of onlookers before boarding the plane.On Thursday the parents to be will travel to the city of Nadi in Western Fiji.

title: hair stylist flips mini cooper roundabout waving
story: Kimberley Howard, , was beeping her horn at a roundabout when she ploughed into a third vehicle being used for a driving lesson in February this year.Her Mini overturned in the crash and ended up on its side leaving Howard with serious injuries.She had to be cut free from the wreckage and suffered lost teeth, bleeding legs and a cut hand and was treated at Wythenshawe Hospital in Manchester.The driver of the L-plated Hyundai car escaped uninjured in the crash on a suburban street in Sale.Police investigated whether Howard from Timperley was on her mobile phone at the time of the impact on February  this year but found no evidence a call was being made.Tests revealed she had cut her hand on the phone when the screen smashed at the point of impact.At Manchester Magistrates Court, Howard who runs a mobile hairdressing service, admitted careless driving but escaped with six penalty points on her licence.She was also fined £ and ordered to pay £ in costs and surcharges.Howard said: I had left my friends house down the road that morning. I came round the roundabout and she was going a dferent way. I beeped and waved at her but I went round the roundabout and then the crash happened. I don’t really remember how it happened.”Prosecuting Tim McArdle said: “It was shortly after lunch time at around .pm. An eye witness was in her vehicle and saw a car beeping in front of her.“She believed it was to attract the attention of another driver. She was beeping at a friend as they travelled around the roundabout.“As she exited the roundabout the car swerved slightly left and hit the passenger side of another car which caused Miss Howard’s car to flip on to its side.“Miss Howard was trapped in the car, her hand was badly cut which could have been from her phone screen as that was smashed.“The police attended and described how after investigating a number of collisions suspected she was distracted by something in the car - it could have been her phone.“Although after checking there was no evidence of a call in progress at the time of the crash, it is unknownit could have been used for something .“She must have been travelling at some speed for the result to be what it was. There were no injuries to others. It was on a Tuesday afternoon in a residential area.”Sentencing chairman of the magistrates Caroline Green told Howard: “I understand you do mobile work so it is very, very important to have your driving licence.“But we need every road user to be conscious and you need to be very, very careful. If you get any more points you will be disqualied.“Something happened on that afternoon and it was a rather nasty accident, and it was fortunate that not more people were hurt.“Given the trauma you have been through medically to get over this incident, you need to be careful - not only for the next three years but for the rest of your driving career.”

title: theresa may summons brexit cabinet
story: NewsTheresa May summons Brexit Cabinet as tension mounts after digging in her heels against the EUThe Prime Minister told MPs the terms of Brexit were % agreed but that the "sticking point" remained the issue of the Irish borderShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political EditorGavin Cordon:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video theresa-says-could-extend-brexit-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May today summoned her Cabinet to debate Brexit as tension mounts over the UKs deadlock with the EU. The Prime Minister briefed ministers after days of Tory infighting and no sign of movement on the thorny issue of the Northern Ireland border. Despite an EU summit falling through with no deal last week, she told MPs the terms of Britains orce were % agreed. To break the deadlock, she offered to either extend Britains transition period beyond December  - or accept a backstop plan with no end date that would keep EU customs rules across the UK. Both plans enrage Brexiteers. But last night she threw them a bone by digging in her heels - against the EU. She again rejected any backstop that would set up dferent rules for Britain compared to Northern Ireland. And she insisted a transition period must end well before May .  Todays Cabinet meeting came on another busy day as time ticks down to Brexit Day on  March .One of Britains top scientists tore into Tory Brexit chaos  Nobel Prize winners raised the alarm over leaving the EU Suppliers of NHS medicine warned No Deal Brexit could need emergency powers to stop drugs running out The head of the National Crime Agency warned crime-fighting will be signicantly impacted by No Deal The latest display of unrest came amid reports almost  - the number needed - Tory MPs have submitted letters to trigger a leadership contest. Some  Brexiteers, including Boris Johnson, have put their names to a public campaign to kill off Theresa Mays plan for Brexit. But there were signs that a series of lurid briefings over the weekend by unnamed backbenchers calling for her to be kned and advising her to bring her own noose had backfired, causing MPs to rally behind her.  International Trade Secretary Liam Fox - a prominent Leave campaigner in the referendum - warned it would be a mistake for MPs to move against the Prime Minister at a crucial moment in the Brexit talks. We are in a process of negotiation. It would seem to be an act of utter folly to change the Prime Minister at this point, he told Sky News during a visit to New York. Andrew Mitchell - an ally of former Brexit secretary David Davis who is seen as a possible leadership contender - also said a leadership challenge would be a mistake. End of October : No Deal preparations have to begin in the UK government no matter what, because otherwise they wont be ready on time.  October : The Budget. It will spell out no deal preparations and be a test of loyalty for the DUP, who are supposed to vote with the government but could rebel. Mid-November : The UK was hoping for a final Brexit summit to seal not just a deal, but a political declaration on future trade. However, this summit still hasnt been approved and may not happen because of splits over how to solve Northern Ireland border. - December : The next scheduled European Council summit. This is the last chance saloon to get a deal. Already its much later than was ideal. Otherwise there wont be time to sign it off before Brexit Day. After a deal is reached: MPs hold a vote on any deal in Parliament. This is danger moment two for Theresa May, who will be in deep, deep troubleshe loses the vote. She claims the UK will leave with No Deal anywayshe loses. But Labour say she should be forced back to the negotiating table call a general election or even trigger a second EU referendum.  March : Brexit Day. If theres a deal, this will be a total anticlimax because a transition will be in place. If theres No Deal, planes could be grounded, ports jammed up and customs checks thrown into chaos at pm.  December : If theres a deal, this is when the transition period - which continues pretty much all the EU rules we have now - is supposed to end. But talk has been floated of extending this by a few months. After December : If theres still no deal, under current plans a backstop would kick in. This could keep the UK tied to EU customs rules, until a proper agreement is reached, in exchange for keeping the Northern Ireland border open. I think it is right to give the Prime Minister every support to conclude a deal, he told BBCs Newsnight. However, he warned Mrs May could struggle to get the support of the House of Commons for any agreement she brings back from Brussels. There is a danger tonight it seems to me that Parliament wont accept that deal or any other deal. That will be a serious problem, he said.  There was further respite for Theresa May when the leading Tory Brexiteer Steve Baker announced he was withdrawing amendments to the Northern Ireland Bill designed to prevent the activation of the so-called Northern Ireland backstop - intended to ensure the border remains open after Brexit. The former Brexit minister - who quit over Mrs Mays Chequers plan for leaving the EU - later welcomed her strong assurance in the House on maintaining the integrity of the UK. The Prime Minister told MPs she could not accept the EUs original backstop plan as it would mean imposing controls on goods traded between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK, creating a customs border down the Irish Sea.  While she was ready to explore every possible option to break the impasse, she said a critical first step should be a legally-binding agreement on a temporary UK-EU joint customs territory to avoid the need for a Northern Ireland-only backstop. As an alternative,at the end of the transition at the end of  a deal on the UKs future relationship with the EU was not quite ready, she said it might by preferable to prolong the transition. However, she stressed any such extension would have to be for a short time only and would have to be over well before the scheduled end of the current parliament in May .

title: tory minister blasted over brexit
story: NewsTory minister blasted over Brexit by top scientist in furious clash as  Nobel prize-winners sound the alarmSir Paul Nurse tore into universities minister Sam Gyimah after  Nobel prize-winners united in a warning about the impact of leaving the EUShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video sam-gyimah-blasted-over-brexit-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Tory minister has been blasted over Brexit by one of the UKs top scientists in a furious live BBC clash. Sir Paul Nurse tore into universities minister Sam Gyimah for letting extremists dominate and demanded he get a grip in a withering attack. It came after Francis Crick Institute director Sir Paul, who won the Nobel Prize in , united with  fellow laureates to sound a warning about the impact of leaving the EU. In a letter to the Prime Minister they warned creating new barriers through Brexit will inhibit progress to the detriment of us all. This morning Sir Paul blasted Brexit chaos as he clashed personally with the Tory universities minister in a rare prime-time debate.  He told Sam Gyimah on BBC Radio s Today programme: We havent seen anything out there that gives us confidence this thing is going to be delivered. I can’t tell you how depressed our young scientists are about all the messages that are coming out of government. This is just awful. I talk to them all the time. You need to get the messaging much better. You need to be much more positive not just about science but what young people can contribute - and the rest of the world. You’re letting your extremists dominate the debate. You’ve got to get a grip of them and stop them sending all these bad messages.  Mr Gyimah insisted he agreed scientists need to be able to come and go under immigration rules and he was prioritising science in Brexit talks. The minister also said unprecedented levels of funding were going into scientic research - an extra poundbillion. But he dodged Sir Pauls question about where poundbillion of lost funding would come from after Brexit. The minister replied: Well... Paul... its... I cant discuss now the shape of the deal we’re going to have.  Today it emerged dozens of winners of the Nobel Prize have written to the Prime Minister and European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker setting out their concerns. Their message was joined by the London-based Francis Crick Institute. Many of us in the science community therefore regret the UKs decision to leave the European Union because it risks such barriers, the group said.  They urged both sides in the Brexit negotiations to ensure as little harm as possible is done to research. The letters signatories include biologist Venki Ramakrishnan, president of the Royal Society. Meanwhile, a survey of more than , staff at the Crick found % of them believed a hard Brexit would be bad for UK science. And % thought it would have a detrimental effect on European science. The Crick is the biggest biomedical research lab under one roof in Europe and has been publicly praised by the Prime Minister, who toured the facility with Indian counterpart Narendra Modi in April.  Sir Paul said: This survey reveals the depth of feeling amongst scientists that a hard Brexit will seriously damage research, and that the UK Government is not paying enough attention to science in the Brexit negotiations. Science and research matter for economic growth, health and quality of le, and the environment. The overwhelming negativity of scientists towards a hard Brexit should be a wake-up call. A hard Brexit could cripple science and the UK Government needs to sit up and listen. We need a deal that replaces the science funding lost because of Brexit, that preserves freedom of movement for talented scientists, and that makes them feel welcome in this country.

title: aldi refused sell bottle whiskey
story: NewsAldi refuses to sell alcohol to dad because his daughter, , was with himThe cashier refused to sell whiskey, lager and bitter to Ken Deeks, , in one of Aldis Manchester storesShareCommentsByHelen JohnsonElaine McCahill:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAldi refused to sell alcohol to a man in his sixties - because he was shopping with his  year old daughter "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAldi refused to sell a -year-old man a bottle of whiskey because he was in the shop with his -year-old daughter. Ken Deeks, , wanted to purchase whiskey and some packs of lager and bitter with his weekly shop at the supermarket in Didsbury, Manchester, last Thursday. However, when he got to the till, the cashier refused to sell it to him because his daughter didnt have ID on her, reports Manchester Evening News . Ken then asked to speak to a manager but they agreed with the cashier and refused to sell him the alcohol. He eventually went back to the store alone several hours later and was allowed to buy the alcohol, but says the policy is ridiculous because he was the one buying the shopping, not his daughter. Aldi meanwhile, says it has apologised to Ken for the inconvenience, but stands by its Challenge  policy.  Ken said: Ive been there with my daughter many times and this is the first time it has happened. Ive been going there since it opened. I told them she wasnt the one who was buying it. My daughter was extremely upset. She went to the car in tears. She was humiliated and embarrassed because the whole shop had heard what was going on. If I go back there again can I go in with her  What about parents with children in trolleys  If someone was going to buy alcohol for a minor, they wouldnt exactly do it with them there. Im absolutely incensed by this. I understand they have to stop people buying alcohol for children, but Im . Im clearly not under . Coupled with the fact that my daughter looks at least  years old they should have used some common sense.  Ken, an exercise therapist from Withington, says he was particularly annoyed about how the store treated his daughter, as she has an anxiety disorder and was extremely upset about the incident. He says that a member of staff announced to a manager that his daughter - who does not wish to be named - had anxiety loud enough for everyone in the shop to hear which left her in tears. Ken added: I wanted to take this up because of the offence caused to my daughter. Im not bothered about me, but Im fuming about what they did to her. What I want from the is a public apology and for them to review their policy. Id also like them to give my daughter a pound gt token or something like it, to say sorry. An Aldi spokesperson said: “We operate a Challenge  policy at all of our stores and staff can apply thisthey think alcohol may be passed to someone underage. We have apologised to Mr Deeks for any inconvenience caused.”

title: devastated mums miscarriage shower due
story: NewsMum blames miscarriage on Tory benefit cuts after stress killed her babyWARNING - DISTRESSING CONTENT: Victoria Bagnall, , from Glasgow, was on benefits after giving up work to care for her husband and sonShareCommentsByAmanda KeenanChris kitching:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsVictoria Bagnall with her husband Gerald Loftus and their two-year-old son Patrick. "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grieving mum claims she suffered a devastating miscarriage at home due to stress caused by Tory welfare cuts and her financial struggle. Victoria Bagnall has been living off benefits and supporting her family after giving up work to care for her ailing husband and their two-year-old son. She claims she begged DWP bosses not to halt her Jobseekeers Allowance payments pound every two weeks - but her pleas were ignored. Within hours, Victoria says, she lost her baby as she had a shower at home, the Daily Record reports. The -year-old, from Glasgow, said: “My doctor told me that my miscarriage could have been brought on by stress.  “I was sick with worry. I have worked all my days and had no idea how we were going to be able to survive with no money. “I was having a shower and suddenly I started bleeding heavily. “The next thing I knew, the foetus came out and I grabbed it. It was tiny and just starting to form. “I could see my baby’s eyes, limbs and even its tiny heart. “I didn’t know what to do. I just cried and held our child in my hands until the paramedics arrived.” Victoria was  weeks pregnant when she was sent a letter from the Department for Work and Pensions on October  telling her they were stopping her Jobseekeers Allowance with immediate effect. She was forced to give up her job as a supervisor at soft play centre Whale of a Time after her partner Gerald Loftus, , tore the cruciate ligament in his knee, leaving him unable to look after their toddler Patrick.  Victoria said: “I’ve worked since the day I left school and I had to give up my job to help care for my partner and son. “This is the first time I’ve claimed benefits in my le and it’s not a position I ever thought I’d be in. “Gerald suffered a stroke  years ago and he also struggles with depression. “We always managed to cope until last month when he injured his knee, leaving him in agony and unable to run around after our son. “Patrick was suffering and Gerald was getting down because he couldn’t look after him properly. “He found it dficult to get about and we don’t have anyone  who can help, so the only option left was for me to give up work. “It wasn’t an easy decision to make and we went from having a regular income to relying on Jobseekers Allowance of pound every two weeks.  “It was a struggle to pay bills, buy food and heat our home, but at least we had some money coming in. I received three payments until I was sent a letter from the DWP saying my benefits were being stopped because I had voluntarily made myself redundant. “I’d already explained the circumstances surrounding my decision to stop working and was told that I could claim benefits – but in a matter of weeks they changed their minds.” The couple were advised to go to their local Jobcentre and apply for Universal Credit but were then told they did not qualy for support. Victoria claims she was also told she wouldn’t be able to receive any JSA payment until February , . Gerald, who worked with Glasgow City Council before his stroke, said: “We begged but the staff showed no interest and basically left us penniless. “They knew Victoria was pregnant and we had a little boy to feed. “I showed them my medical reports but nothing mattered and they refused to help. “We don’t qualy for Universal Credit and I lost my own claim when Victoria moved in with me. We were devastated and very stressed by what we’d been put through.” After suffering the miscarriage, Victoria was rushed by ambulance to the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Glasgow. Related video: A single mum on Universal Credit can’t afford school unorms for kids  Fighting back tears, she said: “I was very stressed and angry at what we’d been put through at the job centre. “The only ray of light was the fact that we were having a little baby and it was something we were all looking forward to. “We always wanted Patrick to have a brother or a sister and it just felt like a blessing. “The pregnancy was going really well and I was due to have our first scan the following week. “When I went into the shower, I felt that something was wrong. “My waters broke and I could feel I was losing the baby. It broke my heart and I just couldn’t believe what was happening. “It was too early to knowour baby was a boy or a girl and I stood with this tiny body in my hands. I didn’t know what to do with it.” “I believe the stress the DWP put me through caused me to lose our baby. “The doctors told me that stress could have been a factor in my miscarriage.  “A post-mortem is taking place and we will know more about what happened in four weeks.” The family are now relying on handouts from a food bank to survive and face an anxious wait to seethe qualy for a hardship payment. Victoria added: “I feel abandoned and badly let down by the DWP. We’ve been left penniless. “We are trying to come to terms with losing our baby and I’m still worrying about how we will make ends meet. “The DWP need to think about the stress they put people under before they cut off vital support.” A DWP spokeswoman said: “We have invited Ms Bagnall to the Jobcentre to discuss the support available. Decisions for JSA are made following consideration of all the information provided by the claimant. “Sanctions are only used in a small percentage of cases, when people fail to meet agreed commitments infor benefits. “People can apply for a hardship payment, which does not have to be repaid back. “Anyone who disagrees with a decision has the right to appeal.” What is Jobseekers Allowance  People can apply for Jobseekers Allowanceto help them as they look for work. First, they must check to seethey are eligible and,they are, make a claim and go to an interview at a local Jobcentre Plus office. Once they receive payments they must keep to their agreement to look for work. Otherwise, the payments will be stopped. There is a maximum amount a person can receive, and how much they are entitled to depends on things such as their age, income and savings. Weekly amounts for couples are up to pound., while people aged  and over can receive up to pound.. Those under  can receive up to pound.. Payments are usually made every two weeks.

Thelemism.Known as the Great Beast, Crowley owned Carn Cottage between St Ives and St Just in Cornwall and used it as a base for his occult practices.He was a sexually-liberated recreational drug-taker long before the s social revolution and followed a "Do what thou wilt" philosophy.Interest in his teachings grew in the s and rock stars such as Jimmy Page were influenced by his ideas.It is said that the cottage was the spot where Crowley summoned the devil himself - story: NewsHunt saboteur lands on her head after falling off gate shaken by angry bloodsport supportersThe young woman, of the West Kent Hunt Saboteurs, crashed into the dirt head-first on WednesdayShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video local-hunt-supporters-cause-female-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA fox hunt saboteur plunged head first to the ground after a group of bloodsport supporters shook a gate as she climbed over it. The young woman is seen crashing into the dirt in the clip shared widely on social media.The elderly men ask the fox hunt saboteurshe has permission to go over the gate in rural Kent before they push and pull the gate as she climbs.It is believed the group are believed to be linked to the Ashford Valley and Tickham Fox Hunt, which the West Kent Hunt Saboteurs were trying to disrupt on Wednesday.  When confronted, one of the men then denies doing anything wrong as his friend stands behind him smirking. But the West Kent Hunt Saboteurs says the woman is very shaken up and claims trolls have targeted them online. Harry Blackhurst, of the group, said: We were following the hunt all day and at this point one of our sabs, the lady, was trying to keep up with the hounds. We were climbing over the gate and those three elderly hunt supporters were shaking the gate purposely to get her off it.  She ended up falling from quite a height onto her shoulders, but luckily she was okay. It could have been an awful lot worse. Shes strained a few muscles in her shoulder and luckily its nothing serious. The gate was at least two metres tall. They didnt care at all. They were saying that theyd done nothing wrong. The -year-old, who is a recruitment consultant from Kent, added: The hunt supporters have come back to us. Weve actually had a lot of online internet trolls that have been trolling us and saying nasty comments.  Our sole aim is to save wildle thats being hunted - principally foxes and hares. A friend of the woman said she was understandably very shaken up She could easily have broken her neck.Ashford Valley and Tickham Fox Hunt and Kent Police were contacted for comment.

title: meghan markle cradles blooming baby
story: NewsMeghan Markle cradles blooming baby bump as she stuns in floor- blue gown at Fiji state banquetIn the clearest image of her bump yet, The Duchess gently placed her hands on her stomach while stood alongside Harry at their evening eventShareCommentsByRussell MyersAbigail OLeary:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMeghan cradles her baby bump "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle cradled her blooming baby bump as she stunned in a floorblue gown at a Fiji state banquet. In the clearest image of her bump yet, The Duchess gently placed her hands on her stomach while stood alongside Harry at their evening event. Meghan dazzled in diamonds to go with the blue, cape dress by label SAFiYAA at a black tie reception on the first night of in Fiji. Her outfit, worn with her hair down, was by German-born London-based designer Daniela Karmuts. Guests, including diplomats, local business leaders and the cream of Fijian society, gathered for the champagne reception ahead of the state dinner at the Grand Pacic Hotel where the royal couple are staying during the visit.  The hotel is a royal favourite, with The Queen staying there five times, in , , ,  and . Prince Charles has checked in three times, in ,  and  and Prince Andrew stayed in . Princess Ann was a guest in . The hotels website states: Once established as the standard of luxury that was fit for royalty now more than  years later, the Grand Pacic Hotel remains true to the ideals of delivering the best of old world charms, South Pacic hospitality and contemporary service.  Earlier today, the royal couple were welcomed to Fiji with a traditional ceremony where they were presented with a roast pig, a whale’s tooth and a taste of the traditional local brew, kava. The ceremony, under cloudy skies in Suva’s Albert Park, mirrored one attended by the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh in . But the weather didn’t stop thousands of people packing the streets leading to Albert Park to greet them. The Duchess of Sussex waved to the crowd from the motorcade, as the couple arrived to cheers for the Veirqaraqarvi Vakavanua where they were greeted by chiefs in a tradition known as the tama. The crowd, slightly damp from the rain shower or “a bit of blessing” as the master of ceremonies put it, cheered and waved Union Jacks and Fijian flags as the couple arrived.  Hundreds maintained reverential silence which is the custom - with only the occasional burst of children chatting or a nearby clock chiming - heard over the rhythmic drums and chanting of the ceremony. Harry and Meghan sat on a stage as he was given the whale’s tooth, a sign of wealth, in the vakasobu, before he were given kava, a drink made from a mashed plant root in the yaqona vakaturaga. Harry, his medals catching the floodlights, looked on as the kava was made with the root wrung out and a bowl passed to the Duke on the stage. The area is known for its strong links to the armed forces and Harry was proudly displaying three medals on his suit, an Afghanistan operational service medal and the Queen Elizabeth II Golden and Diamond Jubilee medals.The Duke and Duchess were also pictured waving from the balcony of the Grand Pacic Hotel to adoring crowds below.

story: NewsMeghan Markle and Prince Harry recreate nostalgic balcony moment of Queen and Prince Philip in same Fiji hotelMeghan Markle and Prince Harry have checked into the Grand Pacic Hotel for their Royal Tour stay in FijiShareCommentsByRussell MyersAbigail OLearyZoe Forsey:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMeghan and Harry wave to crowds from the balcony "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle and Prince Harry recreated a nostalgic balcony moment of the Queen and Prince Phillip in the same Fiji hotel. The Duke and Duchess are staying in the Grand Pacic Hotel in the countrys capital of Suva. The Queen has stayed at the hotel five times, in , , ,  and  - and has waved to crowds from the very same spot as where the Duke and Duchess were pictured. Harry, giving a speech at a state banquet this evening described his and Meghans stay in the hotel as nostalgic. He said: This visit is particularly nostalgic for us as a young married couple – my grandparents stayed in this very hotel, the Grand Pacic, a number of times over the years. Prince Charles has also checked in three times, in ,  and  and Prince Andrew stayed in . Princess Ann was also a guest in .  The hotels website states: Once established as the standard of luxury that was fit for royalty now more than  years later, the Grand Pacic Hotel remains true to the ideals of delivering the best of old world charms, South Pacic hospitality and contemporary service. Harry continued his speech at the hotel reception this evening saying: As you know, Fiji has a long tradition of welcoming Royal visitors over the years and our two countries have enjoyed a close relationship and friendship.We share Commonwealth values and common goals – a love of rugby and a sense of humour! Our ties run deep. Your soldiers fought with the British Armed Forces during the First and Second World Wars and continue to serve alongside our soldiers to this day, with more than , Fijians currently serving.I must emphasise my respect, admiration and camaraderie with the Fijian soldiers that I served with in Afghanistan. We trained together, we fought together, and most importantly we laughed together. Keep up to date with all the latest news from the Queen, Charles, Will, Kate, Harry, Meghan, George, Charlotte Louis and the rest of the family. Well send the best Royal news directly to your inbox so you never have to miss a thing.to our newsletter here.  Meghan and Harry were given a very warm welcome when they arrived in Fiji, and were greeted by a Guard of Honour when their plane landed. They then met President Jioji Konrote before attended an official welcome ceremony in the city centres Albert Park known as the Veirqaraqaravi Vakavanua. The people of Fiji offered them a roast pig, a whale’s tooth and a taste of the traditional local brew kava to Prince Harry and Meghan. The ceremony, under cloudy skies in Suva’s Albert Park, mirrored one attended by the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh in . But the weather didn’t stop thousands of people packing the streets leading to Albert Park to greet them.  The Duchess of Sussex waved to the crowd from the motorcade, as the couple arrived to cheers for the Veirqaraqarvi Vakavanua where they were greeted by chiefs in a tradition known as the tama. Harrys grandparents the Queen and Prince Philip attended a very similar celebration when they visited in . This evening, the Duke and Duchess will attend a black for dinner at the Grand Pacic Hotel, hosted by the president, where the Duke will give a speech. Meghan skipped several events yesterday after a hectic first week of the tour, but is expected to join hubby Harry for all of todays engagements.

title: parents tell kids come home
story: NewsParents tell kids to come home for a wee because of terrible school toilets in new £million buildingOne angry dad called the idea at Ysgol Cwm Brombil, in Port Talbot, south Wales, well out of orderShareCommentsByEstel Farell-RoigBradley Jolly:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsYsgol Cwm Brombil is a new £-million set to open next month "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA new schools decision to have mixed toilets to minimise bullying has been blasted as terrible and well out of order. Ysgol Cwm Brombil, which opens next month in Port Talbot, south Wales, will have mixed toilets in its primary school. Children aged five to  will use the facilities and share a wash area, Wales Online reports. But it has ided the opinion of parents, some of whom have slammed the idea. Daniel Treagus wrote on Facebook: So the new Ysgol Cwm Brombil school apparently have toilets that girls [use] one side and boys the other. However, all in one room.  I certainly think this is well out of order. My kids will be getting front door keys cut so they can use the house for toilet breaks, he added. There are many problems with them. There are possible benefits but the problems outweigh them. Schools should be in the real world. Carol Beckett Jenkins said she thought it was terrible, adding that her granddaughter went to a school that had them and waited to come home to use the toilet. Boys can be cruel at times and dont understand a lot about periods, another mum wrote.  But the local authority says the move will reduce bullying at the poundmillion co-educational which will comprise primary and secondary phases. And other parents have supported the move. Deborah Tucker said: I cant see the problem - it is a great idea and it is working well in the other schools. Embrace it. Its happening, is accepted and working. Councillor Peter Rees, Neath Port Talbot Council’s cabinet member for education, leisure and culture, said the toilets were located just off the main corridors and featured floor to ceiling cubicles with open hand-washing areas.  He said: Whilst this is also the layout at Ysgol Cwm Brombil, the school has chosen to designate facilities on one side of the building as all female and the other as all male, a more traditional set up and one which the flexibility of the design easily allows for. All secondary phase parents have visited the new build over the last two weeks as part of the transition process for when the pupils move in after half term and no concerns were raised at that point regarding the toilet facilities that the school were aware of. Within the primary phase the toilets are mixed, as was the case in the former Groes Primary which Ysgol Cwm Brombil is replacing. Groes was one of the first primary schools to introduce these some years ago and parents have been happy with arrangements.

title: powerlist 2019 100 most influential
story: NewsBlack Powerlist : Meghan Markle is new entry in Top  most influential and powerful black BritonsLenny Henry, Idris Elba, Mo Farah and Thandie Newton have also all made the annual list which recognises those who have changed lives or are making a huge dferenceShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMeghan Markle features in the Top  for the first time "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Sussex Meghan Markle, rapper Stormzy and boxer Anthony Joshua are among  of the most influential and powerful black people in Britain. They have been named in the annual Powerlist, which honours men and women of African and African-Caribbean heritage in Britain who are changing lives. Topping the list at number one is businessman Ric Lewis, who has spent years investing in the futures of underprivileged children. Mr Lewis is also CEO and chairman of private equity real estate asset management firm Tristan Capital Partners - Britain’s largest black-owned and led company. Last year the accolade was awarded to Gina Miller, who led the successful Brexit legal challenge which ruled parliament had to vote on whether Theresa May could trigger Article .  Mr Lewis was number two on the  and  list. He is named alongside new entrant Meghan Markle, editor-in-chief of British Vogue, Edward Enninful, and Ccief executive of Ofcom, Sharon White. Also named on the list are Lenny Henry, Idris Elba, Thandie Newton, Mo Farah and Lewis Hamilton. Mr Lewis said: “I am privileged to have been voted number one for .  Over the course of my career, I have been fortunate enough to accumulate the network and means, which allow me to give back. I hope to use this accolade to continue to advance the charitable causes I feel most passionate about, with the express aim of helping a greater number of children and young adults aspire to and achieve more. I have a deep belief thatkids are provided with inspiration, encouragement and the resources and pastoral care they need, great things can happen for them and for our community. It’s up to all of us to find our own ways to connect the dots and make this happen.”  Powerlist  publisher Michael Eboda said: “One thing that people who know Ric all agree on is that over the years he has become more successful personally and businesswise, but he has never forgotten the charitable causes he believes in. “Topping our Powerlist is never simply about how successful you are in what you do, just as importantly, it’s also about what you do for the good of society as a whole and Ric continues to excel on both fronts.” The Powerlist, now in its th year, honours incredible men and women across a wide range of industries including science, technology and the arts. Guests will be celebrated at a black-tie dinner to be held at Plaisterers’ Hall in London tonight.  At the event, veteran newsreader Moira Stuart will be presented with a Letime Achievement Award for her broadcasting career. She was the first female newsreader of African and African Caribbean heritage in Britain. Entrants were judged on their “ability to change lives and alter events, as demonstrated over a protracted period of time and in a positive manner”. Previous Powerlist number ones, now honoured in the hall of fame, include: campaigner Gina Miller, architect Sir David Adjaye, Sir Damon Buffini, former children’s Laureate Malorie Blackman, philanthropist Mo Ibrahim, Credit Suisse CEO Tidjane Thiam, Baroness Scotland and Baroness Amos. The Powerlist  Top Ten are.... Ric Lewis - Chief executive and chairman of Tristan Capital Partners  Ric Lewis is veteran in the world of international real estate investment management. He serves as chief executive and chairman of Tristan Capital Partners, which has increased its total assets under management by over  per cent in the last year to in excess of € billion. Today, the London-based firm, which Mr Lewis founded in , is regarded as one of the leading real estate investment managers in Europe and is the largest black majority-owned private company in Britain. Outside of work, Mr Lewis is a passionate advocate for removing the barriers to aspiration and achievement for children and young adults, in particular through his own charity the Black Heart Foundation. Each year, the foundation provides educational scholarships to young people in need in the UK and abroad. . Sharon White -Chief executive of Ofcom  Civil servant Sharon White is a highly respected economist and has had a iety of roles in the British civil service. She was the first black person and the second woman to become a permanent secretary at the Treasury. Ms White also worked for the British embassy in Washington, as well as  Downing Street policy unit during Tony Blairs government. She joined Ofcom in March , replacing Ed Richards. . Ismail Ahmed - Founder and CEO of WorldRemit Ltd  Ismail Ahmed founded WorldRemit, a digital money transfer company, following more than  years experience in the industry. The majority of WorldRemit’s customers are migrant workers from the developing world living in developed countries who send money back home to support their friends and family - users can even pay for school fees, utility bills and groceries via their mobile phones. Mr Ahmed holds an MSc and PhD from the University of London and an Executive MBA from London Business School. . Jacky Wright - Chief digital and information officer at HMRC  Jacky Wright joined HMRC in  to take forward its ambitious digital transformation agenda. She has been praised as a seasoned commercial leader with ‘best in class’ credentials, globally. Prior to joining HMRC, she was promoted to corporate vice president of global IT giant Microsoft. She also is one of the most senior black women in tech. Ms Wright is well known in the industry as a transformational global leader and innovative technologist. She is notable in the wide range of recognitions she has received for her work in technology and ersity, both within and external to her work. . Sandie Okoro - Senior vice president and general counsel at World Bank Group  Lawyer Sandie Okoro was appointed as senior vice president and general counsel at World Bank Group in . Prior to those roles, she had been a general counsel of HSBC Global Asset Management and deputy general counsel of HSBC Retail Banking and Wealth Management since . Ms Okoro qualied first as a barrister and then re-qualied and trained as a solicitor. In July , she was awarded an Honorary Doctorate in Law by City University London in recognition of her career in business and law, and her voluntary work. Last year, she was made an Honorary Bencher of Middle Temple. . Ebele Okobi - Facebooks director of public policy for Africa  Ebele Okobi is Facebook’s head of public policy, Africa. Before joining Facebook, Ms Okobi was the founding global head and senior legal director for Human Rights at Yahoo, where she led global efforts to address the legal and policy issues related to privacy, free expression and access. Before that, she was a corporate lawyer at Davis Polk  Wardwell in New York, Paris and London. . Professor Funmi Olonisakin - Vice president and vice principal international at King’s College London  Funmi Olonisakin is a professor of security, leadership and development at Kings College, London. She is also the founder and former director of the African Leadership Centre, which aims to build the next generation of African scholars and analysts generating cutting-edge knowledge for conflict, security and development in Africa. Over her incredible career, she has also worked in the office of the United Nations Special Representative of the Secretary-General on Children and Armed Conflict overseeing the Africa work of that office. The University of Pretoria appointed Ms Olonisakin as an Extra-Ordinary Professor in , building on an earlier award as a Mellon Foundation Distinguished Scholar on Peace and Conflict by UPs Department of Political Sciences in . The Geneva Centre for Security Policy also appointed her as a Distinguished Fellow in April . . Paulette Rowe - Global head of payments and financial services partnerships at Facebook  Last year Paulette Rowe was the most senior Black woman in Barclays UK where she worked as managing director of payments services before joining Facebook. Prior to that she was a marketing director at NatWest, and served as the Commercial and Marketing Director for Tesco Personal Finance. She was also chief executive of Royal Bank of Scotlands European Consumer Financeision, and managing director of Global Payments Acceptance at Barclaycard. . Edward Enninful - Editor-in-chief of British Vogue  For the first time in British Vogue’s -year history, Edward Enninful became the first man - and black person - to take over as editor-in-chief at Vogue. In  he became a contributing editor to Italian Vogue, where he spearheaded the groundbreaking Black Issue featuring only black models, including Naomi Campbell, Jourdan Dunn and Alek Wek. He said he wanted to end the “white-out that dominates the catwalks and magazines”. The issue was so successful that Conde Nast had to print an extra , copies. The day after his  birthday Enninful was appointed i-D fashion director –the youngest ever on an international publication. . Richard Iferenta - KPMG partner and head of challenger banking  Richard Iferenta leads KPMG in the UK’s Challenger banking practice, supporting their institutions with advice across a wide range of services including assurance, risk, tax, regulatory issues and the ever-present digital challenges being faced by the sector. He qualied as a solicitor and is a Chartered Tax Advisor. Prior to KPMG, he worked with two other Big Four firms as well as the city law firm, Simmons  Simmons. Mr Iferenta is a well-known tax practitioner who excels at making the complex simple, as well as supporting his clients in delivering innovative approaches to address a range of tax issues. story: NewsPrince Harrys incredible response when being told to end conversation with grieving woman by staffPrince Harry spent ten minutes chatting to Gwen Cherne, and the pair even shared an emotional hug during the Royal TourShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video poignant-moment-prince-harry-comforts-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Harry has proved on many occasions he has definitely inherited his mums compassion, and its been no dferent on his first Royal Tour with Meghan Markle . The Duke of Sussex has taken the time to speak to well-wishers and people from the organisations he has visited to learn everything he can. So when a member of his staff tried to hurry him along when he was chatting to a grieving widow during his Sydney Harbour Bridge climb, its hardly surprising he wasnt best pleased. Gwen Cherne, , was one of a group of guests invited to take on the challenge with the prince and told him about her husband Australian special forces officer Peter J. Cafe, who committed suicide last year.  They spend ten minutes chatting, and even shared an emotional hug. But then Harrys staff tried to move him along before the conversation was over, reports People . Gwen said: He stopped and said, Im in a middle of a conversation, and Im not going to leave this. We were talking about my story and mental health and how dficult it is still, in our society, to talk about grief and loss and suicide.  And how important things like the Invictus Games are to shedding light on, and allowing people to start to have these conversations that are great to have. Peter served in Cambodia, Afghanistan and Iraq, and since his death Gwen has become an Invictus and War Widows Guild ambassador. title: teenager took life just 24
story: NewsTeenager took her own le just  hours after she was declared not an immediate risk by mental health nurseHeather Donlin had a long history of mental health problems but when she saw a nurse in February they did not think she was in immediate dangerShareCommentsByTristan Cork:,  OCT NewsHeather Donlin and her mum Tara who was too emotional after the inquest to speak about the death of her daughter"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A teenager who took her own le was declared not an immediate risk by a mental health nurse less than  hours before her death. An inquest heard that Heather Donlin had a long history of mental health problems , including suicide attempts, self-harm, panic and anxiety. But Heather was discharged as a patient by the Avon and Wiltshire mental health partnershiptwo months before she took her own le in February, reports Bristol Live .Avon Coroners Court heard that the teenager had struggled to attend appointments due to anxiety and at times as unable to leave her home at all. She was told by AWP that she should go to her doctors instead.  During those two months after she was discharged and before her death in February this year, the -year-old attended AE a number of times having taken overdoses or threatened to take her own le. She was admitted to AE four times in total in the  months leading up to her death, and on a number of occasions, Heather’s mum Tara asked doctors at hospital to detain her daughter under the Mental Health Act, but she never was ‘sectioned’. Coroner Peter Harrowing heard that in late January and early February, her mental health deteriorated. In late January this year, she called the mental health Crisis team to tell them she wanted to take her own le, and was told to call her social worker. On the last day of January, she smashed up her bedroom at the family home in Fishponds, and police were called. On February  went to her local GP, Katrina Whalley, who described her as being ‘distraught’ and said that she was going to take her own le. So she sent a request that Heather was contacted by mental health professionals within  hours. The inquest heard she was called the same day, and an appointment arranged for February , but at am that morning, she called AWP’s Crisis Team to say she wouldn’t be able to come as she was having trouble sleeping. An appointment was rearranged for February , and she attended the mental health centre in Speedwell, where she saw mental health nurse Ashley Russell. Mr Russell told the coroner that he had read up on Heather’s history, and knew she had previously indicated ‘suicidal ideations’. But that morning she didn’t, and reassured Mr Russell she would be able to keep herself safe. “She engaged well. I felt we established a rapport,” he said. “She was distressed and tearful at times. She was dressed appropriately for the time of year,” he added. Mr Russell said Heather told him about the instability of her living arrangements - she split her time between her girlfriend’s and her family home - and about how she previously attempted to take her own le in the weeks previously. “I asked her specicallyshe had a plan to harm herself, she said ‘no’. “I did not consider she was an immediate risk to herself, and she was actively seeking our help. She said she would like to find stable accommodation and more stable relationships, and that we would work to help with her anxiety and panic. “There was medication that was needed immediately,” he added. There was no evidence there was an immediate risk, but there was a concern about the ongoing suicidal thoughts. Mr Russell left Heather with his number, and the number of the Crisis Team, and a plan to get back in touch in the coming days, after he had spoken to the person who dealt with her care the previous year, and her social worker. But tragically, the following morning, February , Heather was due to meet her mum in the city centre but said she wasn’t able to get a lt into town. Heather’s mum Tara ed to find she had taken her own le that morning.  Coroner Peter Harrowing recorded a conclusion that Heather took her own le. A spokesperson for Avon and Wiltshire Mental Health Partnership said: “We’d like to offer the family of Heather Donlin our sincere condolences.” Heather’s mum Tara was too upset to talk following the inquest. After her death earlier this year, she raised questions about her care, being discharged from AWP care because she was too ill to get to appointments, and why she was not sectioned despite repeatedly being admitted to AE following overdoses or other attempts to take her own le. In the midst of Tara’s grief, just four days later, she let off a smoke grenade in the middle of council chamber’s public gallery during Bristol City Council’s annual budget meeting, in protest at cuts to social services, mental health services and young people’s services. In the middle of her protest, she said: “Shewasn’t just failed by myself, she was failed by social services, mental health services. Andyou make any cuts to those services you are going to have a hell of a lot of blood in this council chamber. “My daughter has been killed by the system, and I am angry,” she added. After her death, tributes poured in for Heather, who went to Bristol Brunel Academy and her funeral was well attended. “She was one of the sweetest, craziest, funniest, grumpiest people you could ever meet, all rolled into one gorgeous person,” said her mum Tara. “There are no words I can use to express what an amazing person she is and the way I feel about her,” she added.If you are affected by any issues raised in this story, contact The Samaritans for confidential support on  .

title: woman popped stitches after smelling
story: NewsWoman popped her stitches after smelling rancid chicken breasts bought at Iceland storeEmma Drew, from Rhondda, Wales, was given the dodgy chicken fillets by her mum while recovering from keyhole surgeryShareCommentsByKathryn Williams:,  OCT NewsEmma Drew from the Rhondda became sick from the smell of the Iceland chicken breasts"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman claims she popped her stitches from after smelling rotten chicken bought from an Iceland store in Wales.Emma Drew, , was given a box of chicken fillets from the stores Port Talbot branch on Sunday, Wales Online reported .She only noticed something was wrong after her partner opened the packaging at their home in Rhondda, Wales. The resulting odour was so powerful she says she began to retch uncontrollably. Emma explained: My partner, who cant smell a lot thanks to his days playing rugby, said have a smell of this, and as I went over to it I thought oh my god. Seconds later I was throwing up. It was disgusting. The -year-old from Treherbert, who has endometriosis and has just had her eighth op to treat the condition, ed home from hospital last Wednesdayand has been recovering since. The keyhole surgery left her with stitches in her stomach and unable to walk much further than the bathroom.  Emma added: I was retching, I could feel there was something wrong and I took the bandage off my belly button and it was bleeding. I had to take morphine for the pain it caused. When you have this operation, the quicker you can get off the morphine and start moving around the better, but after the vomiting and the pain it caused, Ive had to go back on the morphine. It makes me feel awful, really lethargic. Emma, who works at the YMCA in Cardf, said: I told my mother what happened and so she checked her chicken and it was the same.  Her mother then took the packets - which had three days left before the use by date was up, on October  - to nearby Treorchy Iceland. They wouldnt give my mother a refund and they took the chicken from her. She then phoned customer services where they still refused to refund the cost and said theyd give her the equivalent back on her Iceland card. I just couldnt believe they didnt give her the money back. They were meant to be fresh chickens, its not like they had a yellow sticker on the packet or it was the middle of summer.  In follow up calls to the Port Talbot Iceland store, Emma also discovered that the message about the chicken had not been relayed to them from the Treorchy branch. A spokeswoman for Iceland Foods Ltd said: Iceland takes all complaints about our food quality extremely seriously and we are sorry that this product appears to have fallen short of both our and the customer’s expectations and a detailed investigation is already underway. We have been in touch with Ms Drew and requested her to contact our Customer Care department, where we can apologise for the distress this situation has caused and we will ensure a full refund and goodwill gesture is arranged.

story: NewsBride who miraculously defied doctors and lived to celebrate her wedding day dies after brave cancer fightLaurin Bank was so ill that doctors urged her and partner Michael to bring forward their wedding day, but they refusedShareCommentsByDave Burke:,  OCT NewsLaurin Bank was urged to bring her wedding day forward, but she refused "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bride who defied the odds by miraculously surviving until her wedding day has died after a long cancer battle.
