title: letters to the editor week 39
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated -days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as  pence per week.Sir,I was delighted to read Stuart White#s letter in the September  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser, and I could not agree with him more.It is certainly more than time we shook off # or at least drastically reduced # the inefficient and over-subsidised wind farming. As he says, it is far too dependent on the vagaries of the weather.Tidal power can never fail and here in Mid Argyll we have potentially the most efficient and cost-effective tidal system under our noses. This, in turn, would open up additional tourist and recreational facilities at virtually no extra cost. This would be a win-win situation, but without, I suspect, sufficient profit to satisfy the usual parasitic financial interests.What is this simple and relatively inexpensive answer Simply build a sea wall or dam, call it what you will, across the relatively narrow entrance of Loch Gilp from the Lingerton promontary towards Ardrishaig via the rocky skerries, which would reduce the cost, and finish short of the Ardrishaig lighthouse harbour wall, thus funneling all the tides through a very narrow area.Then simply incorporate as many sea locks and gates as needed to allow passage of boats in and out of the harbour and the Crinan Canal.The additional locks would be used for either lower-able turbines or permanently submerged tidal units such as in the Pentland Firth. This would be simple and cost-effective, as the generating turbines catch the tides both in and out. After all, the Romans were using tide mills , years ago, so the idea is nothing new.In addition to this, Ardrishaig would finish up with an enhanced harbour  and marina and, with a few rocks removed from the beach, the wide open area at low tide back to Lochgilphead # now wasted # would make a splendid international course for activities such as land yacht racing.The other deceitful cuckoo that we should consider debunking is the very misleading fallacy that electric cars are helping to save the planet. Yes, it is ideal and justied for town or city use to keep the fume level down in densely built up areas where fresh air is in short supply among high buildings. But generally their use is unjustiable because pollution would actually increase considerably overall because to generate every single power unit of electricity it takes roughly two polluting units of other fuels such as coal, oil or even gas to produce that single electrical unit.So, unless the electricity is always generated from renewable systems such as hydro, tidal, solar or wind, then total pollution would go up, not down.One more cuckoo destined to be the sham of another expensive white elephant.Bob Henderson, LochgilpheadSir,We would like to say a huge thanks to all the bands who played on the Sunday of this year#s Tarbert Music Festival for making it a successful afternoon after the event had to be moved from the quay to the village hall # this has to be our most stressful decision.Thanks to all the hotels and pubs for organising the great music for the weekend.We raised just over £ at the coffee morning, so thanks to everyone who baked or donated and also to all the helpers # Anne, Gail,Jane, Allie, Nina and Zena.Many thanks also to the award-winning Mid Argyll Pipe Band, who entertained a huge crowd in the pouring rain and also the Loch Fyne Pipe Band who played to the Sunday survivors.To Mrs Brown, our very own collector extrondanaire, her wee buckets totalled £.Finally, and most importantly, thanks to visitors and locals for turning out to support our music festival.Thank you all.Margaret, Duncan, Barbara and Kirsten of Tarbert Music FestivalSir,The National Autistic Society is looking for people and organisations who have done something amazing for autistic children, adults, or their families.Perhaps it’s a teacher who has helped a child achieve something great, an autistic adult who has been campaigning tirelessly or a business that has put a lot of effort into making their workplace accessible.If any of your readers know of a person or organisation like this, please nominate them for our seventh annual Autism Professionals Awards. We want to celebrate their achievements, so we can improve understanding of autism and inspire other people and organisations to make a dference too. Find out more about autism and nominate by visiting the www.autismprofessionalsawards. org.uk website.Carol Povey, director, National Autistic Society’s Centre for AutismSir,Research funded by the British Heart Foundation has helped halve death rates from heart and circulatory diseases over the past  years, and so much of our work has only been possible thanks to the amazing iniduals who have remembered the BHF in their will.I would personally like to honour these people and express our gratitude for the research breakthroughs and thousands of lives they have helped to save.A gt of any size, after you’ve provided for your loved ones, will enable the BHF to continue to fund pioneering research to find future cures and treatments into heart and circulatory conditions.To find out more about leaving a gt in your will and to download a free wills guide, please visit bhf.org.uk willsSimon Gillespie, chief executive, British Heart Foundation

title: ayrshire student launches campaign against
story: NewsAyrshire student launches campaign against spikingCara’s drive to keep young women safer when they’re out on the town.ShareByPippa Smith:,  OCT NewsCara Taven has launched a Facebook page named Girls Against Spiking. "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA campaign has been set up to raise awareness of people having their drinks spiked. Cara Taven, from Coylton, set up a Facebook page called ‘Girls Against Spiking’to bring to light the effects of spiking on nights out and to, hopefully, eradicate it. The Facebook page, which has gained a following of over  people in one week, hopes to attract the attention of nightclubs and bars and is aiming for lids to be put on all drinks served at their bars as part of a drive to stop people having their drinks spiked.  Cara, , told the Post about her campaign. She said: “I have heard a lot about people getting spiked recently, in my local area and in the Glasgow region, and I know that a lot of people in Ayr do go out in Glasgow. “It tends to be younger girls about my age that get affected by spiking and that was something I have really started to think about. “This is something that could happen to anyone. “I’m a law student and the reason why I wanted to study law was to represent people who maybe don’t have the confidence to represent themselves and to make a dference that way and I think that is where getting the idea to make the page has come from. “I honestly thought it would be a page where the girls at my work could like – I am surprised by the response. “I remember saying to someone at work ‘If you like the page it’ll take me to  likes’ – then when I woke up in the morning and it was . “I haven’t been affected by spiking – it’s not really about me or anyone that I know. It is about the community of girls my age. “ I just felt like the answer was there and no one has done anything about it until now.” The Post reported how Cleo Smillie, , from Ayr, was on a night out in Madrid with her friend, Marc Davies, when she blacked out after one sip of her pink gin and lemonade. It was later learned that she had a high level of GHB in her blood – the date-rape drug. Strathclyde Union is among the nightclubs and bars that were prompted by the campaign and have gone on to order  lids on a trial basis as they work on ways to keep students as safe as possible on nights out.

title: bob shields latest column golf
story: Jim Ronneyleft and Russ Stewart ."Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLess than a year ago – in this very column – I argued the case for an Ayrshire coastal “commission” that would monitor every development that might affect our precious shoreline. An astute, respected and independent body, its remit would be to act for the long term greater good of the Ayrshire coast and its stakeholders - and issue unorm guidelines to prevent North, East and South Ayrshire councils peppering our seascapes with all kinds of piecemeal shoreline developments. Sadly, such a badly-needed supervisory power is still only a figment of my imagination. But had it existed – it would have poured over builder McCarthy and Stone’s ‘Legoland’ plans for the former Malcolm Sargent House site at Prestwick . . . before hobbing them into the nearest bin! As it is, neighbouring Prestwick Golf Club have taken the legal ‘ last resort’ and petitioned for a judicial review of South Ayrshire Council’s decision to grant planning approval. Successfully overturning SAC’s November  decision is the legal equivalent of holing a  footer on Prestwick’s th green. Only six per cent of inidual judicial reviews succeed. But they can take comfort in the classic  judicial review when planning permission for wind turbines was challenged because they were in the flight path of ospreys nesting hundreds of miles away! Lord Hope ruled that while no inidual with land interests had objected to the turbines, the “natural environment” is everyone’s interest. He memorably pronounced: “The osprey has no means of protecting itself. If its interests are to be protected, someone needs speak on its behalf”. Prestwick’s Golf Club’s members are scattered across the county, the country and the world. Not a single one of them has inidual land interests affected by the proposed development. But the  Tom Morris designed links - its fairways, dunes, greens, unique location, backcloth, traditions and history - cannot protect itself. In the spirit of Lord Hope’s ruling, its members are “speaking on its behalf”. And I say good luck to them. As I also said, their chances on paper are slim. Butit hits the Court of Session, and the man in the big seat has a Royal and Ancient tie under his robe – or bits of Muirfield on the golf shoes in the boot of his Jag - well . . . you just never know! Prestwick’s members are no fools either – they hope their legal move will get everyone back around the table for complete rethink on the scale of McCarthy and Stone’s plans. The builder will no doubt deny any adverse reflection on Prestwick – but you can bet the proximity of the historic links will be in the first paragraph in any of their sales brochures! McCarthy and Stone made a pound million profit in . Their average UK apartment price is almost pound, - and they’re planning  of them at Prestwick . . . that’s pound. million. With those numbers at stake – McCarthy and Stone will be putting all kinds of pressure on South Ayrshire Council not to cave in. Prestwick Golf Club doesn’t have a problem with the site being developed – but rightly ask that any development be appropriate in design and scale to its noble and historic surroundings. And that’s something McCarthy and Stone can easily afford. Prestwick Golf Club is a legendary place for winners. And there will be legendary amounts of Kummel quaffed in the clubhousethey win this one!Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilEnvironmentPrestwickAirAsiaAyr

title: chief inspector makes return south
story: NewsChief inspector makes ato South AyrshireChief Inspector Derek Frew takes over the reigns from Gary I’Anson.ShareByPippa Smith:,  OCT NewsChief Inspector Derek Frew "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe new chief inspector in South Ayrshire has vowed to put the community at the heart of policing. Derek Frew has been announced as the new Area Commander for South Ayrshire Police. The -year-old takes over the reigns from Gary I’Anson. Having joined the police service in June  and been serving for  years, chief inspector Frew started off his probation in Ardrossan, Saltcoats and Stevenston.Ayrshire student launches campaign against spikingThe dad-of-two then went on to work in the communities across Ayrshire, most notably as the local bobby in Millport, where he lived from  to  with his we and two sons. In recent years, he has worked on national policing reform and been part of the Corporate Communications department. Before taking up his new post, he worked for the Scottish Multi-Agency Resilience, Training and Exercise Unit . Speaking to the Post, the chief inspector, declared: “Since I left school I had always wanted to join the police - with my traditional up bringing, I wanted to be part of the community. “As an operational officer, I have always worked in Ayrshire - when I first joined I started in the three towns, finished my probation and then moved to Millport as the local bobby. “It was an interesting but good experience - my family were young at the time - it was a Hamish MacBeth lestyle where I had the house that was built on to the police station. “What you learn at that point when you’re working yourself is in the winter you are working with your local community, but when you’re working throughout the summer time, you have the tourists - this is when the island community went from  upto , a day and you are still working yourself with the help of special constables. This is when you learn your people skills. I was there for three and a half years - you involve yourself with the community - it was just amazing. “It was a highlight for personal reasons, for family reasons, for friends you make for le and for the grounding it gives you in getting to know people. “I came back to Ayr in  as an operational police officer then I left the Division and worked in national security for a while which was really interesting. “It got to  and I wanted to come back to operational policing so I ed to Ayr as an operational inspector. “For the third time in my career, I’m back. To be a police officer, an inspector and now get the position of Area Commander in Ayr and to have lived, studied and met my we in Ayr, both personal and professional is just great. “The whole ethos of policing, for me, is community. “I am absolutely delighted to be Area Commander of South Ayrshire and I would like to thank Chief Inspector Gary I`Anson for everything that he has done for South Ayrshire and the key role that he has played over the last few years.”

story: NewsRats on loose in Ayrshire High Street as terried business owners forced to kill verminThe plague of vermin has hit Girvans Dalrymple Street and furious business owners say enough is enough.ShareCommentsByStuart Wilson:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsGus Kilgour is among those being plagued "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn army of giant RATS is stalking town centre shops and homes. The outbreak in Girvan has sparked panic among business owners battling to control the vermin. Hygiene chiefs this week slapped an emergency order on the town’s derelict former bingo hall housing the filth. And furious community leaders say the pest problem is turning their town into a no-go zone. Bill Logan, who heads Girvan’s Youth Trust, said: “We’re trying to promote ourselves as a tourist town which is open for business. “How can you do that with rats running all over the street and into shops  “I feel for businesses – it’s ridiculous they should have to put up with this.” The long-running decay of the former bingo hall and cinema was highlighted this week when rats were spotted running loose.  A number of shops in Dalrymple Street are being plagued, causing council environmental teams to swoop. Elaine Murdoch, owner of Nanettes baby shop, revealed: “Luckily I haven’t had one in yet –I did I think I’d close. “A rat ran into another shop the other day and the poor woman was hysterical. “This has been a long time coming as the state of the building is a disgrace.” South Ayrshire’s Tory council chief, Martin Dowey, is among those to have witnessed the vermin first hand. He said: “I was delivering leaflets in the town last week and one ran right in front of me. It was half the size of a cat, I couldn’t believe what I was seeing. “You have to feel for the businesses and homeowners and hopefully this is rectied as soon as possible.” A council spokesman confirmed a seven-day action order has been placed on the building.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeCommentsShow more commentsMore OnArmed forcesGirvanAyr NewsAyr

title: world wonder through looking glass
story: NewsWorld of wonder through the looking glass at Hendricks GinIt’s the tipple sought after and enjoyed by millions across the globe but made closer to home than you think – in the heart of Girvan.ShareByAbi Smillie:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsWhere the magic happens Hendricks Gin Palace "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email“A gin made oddly”– put simply by the gin gods themselves – Hendrick’s. It’s the tipple sought after and enjoyed by millions across the globe but made closer to home than you think – in the heart of Girvan. And it’s at the newly developed multi-million pound Hendrick’s Gin Palace where the magic and wonder begins. The most signicant development since launch in , Hendrick’s Gin has been impressively expanded to meet the global demand for the ever popular drink. William Grant  Sons, the family owned independent global spirts company, has invested pound million in the glorious expansion, adding six new distillers to work under Hendrick’s Master Distiller, Lesley Gracie’s watchful eye. Innovation has always been in the brand’s DNA, echoing the ethos of Lewis Carroll who cried “curiouser and curiouser”. And it’s this spirit of invention and Alice in Wonderland-esque manner that carries through to the custom-designed complex which is encased in an enchanted walled garden, leading to a magnicent “Victorian inspired” palm house.  Surrounded by two botanical hot houses, the palm house is used to “cultivate unusual botanicals and flora from around the world”. An inner sanctum that is Lesley’s laboratory features a “curious flavour library, a lecture theatre that encourages scholarly learnings and a suitably stylish bar”. And, of course, there are two stunning new still houses. The Hendrick’s family of stills now stands at a proud six – four Bennett stills including the original antique copper pot from  and three precise replicas. The Bennett stills were handcrafted by local manufacturers Carrick Engineering and construction of the distillery was all done by local contractors and builders helping to capture the home of Hendrick’s gin right down to the foundations. The three replica stills are guarded and overlooked by a stunning stained glass ceiling – perhaps spied by Alice herself as she keeked through the looking glass. Master distiller Lesley continues that sense of wonder with every drop she makes.  Lesley said: “I’ve been distilling Hendrick’s for almost  years and during that time, my team and I have had the opportunity to explore and experiment on a small scale. “However, I’m thrilled and excited to take full advantage of our wonderful new distillery and begin working on a line of experimental liquids, some of which will hopefully blossom into future releases and potential new expressions of Hendrick’s.” Pamela Selby, the Global Brand Director for Hendrick’s added: “The Hendrick’s Gin Palace in its design and experience, is intended to inspire curiosity, open minds and serve as a  for invention. “It pulls back the curtain on the wondrous production method and showcases the many layers of Hendrick’s that it has become celebrated for, some humorous, others curiously intellectual, detailed and deeply meaningful. “It represents the confidence we have in the brand that helped to kick-start the ginaissance and leading role it has played ever since.” And with no end in sight for the beloved ginaissance – long may it live. At Alice in Wonderland’s top table it’s time for tea, but at the glorious Hendrick’s Palace it’s always gin o’clock.

title: weekend-of-stories-opens-new-chapter-for-house-built-on-words
story: LITERARY sessions are set toto their rightful place later this month.In the early th century, the centre of the British literary world was not to be found amongst the publishing houses of London or Edinburgh or in the fashionable salons of Mayfair or Piccadilly.It stood on the banks of the Tweed.Abbotsford was the house built on words, the home of the first worldwide bestselling author, Sir Walter Scott, and it was a magnet and a mecca for writers, artists and great intellectuals.William Wordsworth, Lord Byron, JMW Turner, Sir Humphrey Davy and many others basked in the glow of Scottrsquos reputation and the warmth of his fabled hospitality.And even after his death in , Abbotsford became a shrine, attracting pilgrims such as Charlotte Bronte and Charles Dickens.Five years ago, the house was gloriously restored, a wonderful new visitor centre built and now with the launch of the Abbotsford Literary Sessions, old traditions are about to be revived.Writers are coming back to Scottrsquos house.Launching on October  and , four very dferent authors will discuss their new books in Ochiltreersquos Cafeacute.In association with Baillie Gford and the Abbotsford Trust, Paula Ogilvie and Alistair Moffat have compiled a programme - two double bills over two evenings.At pm on the Saturday Simon Jenkins, former editor of The Times and bestselling author, will talk about A Short History of Europe ndash from Pericles to Putin.Europe has for two millennia been a remarkably successful continent. Yet, despite the importance of its politics, economy and culture, there has not been ndash until now ndash a concise book to tell this story.Simon has written a gripping account of its evolution ndash a story that twists and turns from Greece and Rome to the Second World War and up to the present day.Also on the Saturday Ben Macintyre will talk about his new book, The Spy and the Traitor.Described by the master of the fictional genre, John le Carreacute, as lsquothe best true spy story I have ever readrsquo, the thrilling cold war tale is simply astonishing.This fascinating account reveals the amazing story of Britainrsquos most successful Russian agent and is a tale of espionage and betrayal which changed the course of the Cold War.At pm on the Sunday, Penny Junor will offer a lighter touch with her All the Queenrsquos Corgis.It is an affectionate and entertaining look at the relationship Elizabeth II has with her most faithful companions. She looks at the dogs that have been bred, owned by and given to the Queen throughout her le, revealing a very private side that is seldom seen.Neuroscientist Joseph Jebelli will complete the Abbotsford Sessions with a talk about his In Pursuit of Memory ndash The Fight Against Alzheimerrsquos.This wonderful, moving book unpacks the facts and realities behind a more common killer than cancer, and explores the past, present and future of Alzheimerrsquos disease starting from the very beginning. It is a story as riveting as a detective novel.A rich, ied programme - exactly the sort of thing that would have made Sir Walter smile.The Abbotsford Literary Sessions in association with Baillie Gford take place at Abbotsford Visitor Centre on Saturday, October  with Simon Jenkinsand Ben Macintyre , and Sunday, October  with Penny Junorand Joseph Jebelli .Ticketsavailable from www.litsessions and   .

title: borders-chapter-of-book-week-scotland-announced
story: A WEEK of literary events has been announced in the Borders as part of Book Week Scotland .Between November  and  the Scottish Book Trust is set to deliver hundreds of free events and activities, funded by Scottish Library and Information Council, throughout Scotland.Crime writer Aline Templeton will visit Melrose Library on November  from pm to pm to talk about her journey from a six-year-old aspiring writer to the author of The Third Sin, the latest title in her popular Galloway-based crime fiction series.Borders writer Jules Horne will visit Hawick Library on November  and  from .pm to .pm to present a spoken word performance of modern Border ballads and nanonovels in Scots and English.She will be accompanied by stand-up cello and loop station and the performance will feature the Borders Heritage Festival Commission Three Border Songs and a touch of Borders Gothic.Local writer Margaret Skea will give an illustrated presentation on her -mile solo research trip to the former German Democratic Republic in search of Katharina von Bora - the nun who became the we of the controversial reformer Martin Luther.Margaret will also discuss her award-winning book that was a result of this search, Katharina: Deliverance, at the event at Galashiels Library on November  from .pm and .pm.Writers interested in self-publishing are being encouraged to attend CABN Indie Author Gathering on November , am - pm, at Galashiels Library.Promising an insight into the world of self-publishing, the event will provide an opportunity to meet like-minded writers, show and sell books, share information, and learn from other authors experiences.Culture Secretary Fiona Hyslop said: ldquoAs a le-long and avid reader, I know that therersquos no greater pleasure than losing yourself in the magic of a book.ldquoThatrsquos why I welcome this fantastic launch of  Book Week Scotland programme, a flagship event of Scotlandrsquos culture sector celebrating books, reading and Scotlandrsquos rich literary history and dedicated this year to exploring the theme of lsquoRebelrsquo.The seventh national celebration of books and reading was launched in Edinburgh where drag queen and Book Week Scotland ambassador, Nancy Clench, and bestselling author Claire Askew, posed with copies of the Rebel book, which features a story from Nancy, as well as others submitted from the public.Marc Lambert, CEO of Scottish Book Trust, said: ldquoWersquore delighted to present another packed programme for Book Week Scotland, our national celebration of reading and writing.ldquoAfter listening to feedback, Scottish Book Trust is pleased to make , copies of the Rebel book available to the public.ldquoMany thanks to our partners and funders for making this programme possible, and we hope everyone joins us for Book Week Scotland, whether at a physical event, or by taking part in our Digital Festival.Erin McElhinney, Literature Officer, Creative Scotland, commented: ldquoScottish Book Trust have produced a programme that offers a whole host of routes into reading and writing, offering a cause to the rebel in all of us.ldquoItrsquos a week to celebrate new partnerships and connections, between organisations and the public, between digital and the book ndash and an invitation to challenge our own boundaries around reading.For information on events visit https:bookweekscotlandevents

Melrose, Galashiels, Earlston and Hawick as well as Selkirk.Kelso pupil Olivia Ferguson, who came up with the idea for the Springwood event, told us: ldquoIt is taking off with so many people coming forward to support and lots of schools talking about it now which is fantastic."But schools still need to sign up before the October  deadline."It was great to get the support and enthusiasm from Selkirk High staff and students, and the wonderful Quarriers staff now supporting students in Borders schools."That means we will have plenty of PVG-disclosed adults at the event, along with teachers who have been brilliant in coming forward to offer their support."During the Wee Sleep Out local singer-songwriter Erin Highton will be performing, along with the popular M-Pulsive Dancers and DJ Pries.Presenters from Radio Borders will also take to the Springwood Park stage.And organisers hope to announce more entertainment acts in the coming weeks.Olivia also revealed: "Robertsonrsquos Buses have offered to pick up people from across all the Berwickshire school areas, Borders Buses are going to run buses from Galashiels, Selkirk and Hawick, passing through Jedburgh, and Austin Travel are picking up in Earlston and Melrose."And their brilliant drivers are going to be there at .am on Sunday morning to take everyone back to their schools!"Thatrsquos huge and wersquod like to thank them, the Border Union Agricultural Society, Kelso Laddies Association, teachers and our entertainers for getting behind the event."Wersquore also speaking to catering companies and would like to hear from anyone who wants to support our part in the campaign to end homelessness.The event is open to all school-children aged eight years old and over, although schools and youth organisations will need a PVG-disclosed adult to sign their group up on the Social Bite website - www.sleepinthepark wee-sleep-out - before October .The Scottish Government last week pledged pound.m to Social Bitersquos campaign.The charityrsquos co-founder Alice Thompson is delighted that further support is coming from across the country - including the Borders.She stated: ldquoThe Borders has really taken to Livvyrsquos Wee Sleep Out in Kelso and wersquore supporting her and the Kelso and Selkirk schools to attract as many young people as possible."The venue can take up to  so there is plenty of space for those who want to spend a night in their sleeping bags supporting our campaign to end homelessness."But get signed up before the deadline.

title: german-archaeologists-uncover-the-secrets-of-torwodlee-and-trimontium
story: A MAJOR survey by German archaeologists has uncovered important fresh finds on historic sites near Melrose and Galashiels.Last week members of the German Archaeological Institute helped carry out the largest single geophysical survey ever performed in the Scottish Borders at Trimontium.And they also undertook extensive work at Torwoodlee.The week-long expedition, which was co-sponsored by the Trimontium Trust and the German government, was led by RGKs Dr Ruth Beusing.Along with her team important new geophysical discoveries were made at and around the hillfort at Torwoodlee.And the survey of Trimontium has produced never before seen details of the site.Dr John Reid, chair of The Trimontium Trust, told the Border : "This has been a fantastic once in a letime collaboration with such a well-organised and efficient team."We have been privileged to have the full resources of the RGK behind this project which has revealed the site in astonishing detail."The team has worked from dawn until dusk to create what represents the most detailed images ever produced of a Roman fort in Scotland."Many new discoveries have been made which will be revealed over the next couple of months as Dr Beusing and her team process the terabytes of data on theirto Frankfurt."The Trimontium Trust is hugely grateful to Mr James Pringle at Torwoodlee and Mr Paul Rooney at Newstead for their generous permission to investigate the sites."It has moved forward our thinking on a number of key aspects of the Roman occupation."The project was aimed at investigating the possible relationship between the invading Roman forces of Trimontium and the indigenous population living at the Torwoodlee hillfort.James Pringle, owner of Torwoodlee, told us: "The more we can discover about our past and our history, the more we will be able to understand what has made us the people we now are."Perhaps that will help us to plot a path through the future with greater and better vision for our communitys well-being."Dr Beusing and her team willto Torwoodlee next year to carry out further survey work.And in the coming weeks the Trimontium Trust will unveil details of the discoveries made on the Roman site near Newstead.Dr Christopher Bowles from Scottish Borders Council believes the week-long survey is vitally important for helping to understand our local history - and it carries on the work of other great archaeologists.He said: "In the early part of the th century two brothers from Melrose, James and Alexander Curle, revolutionised archaeology not just in Scotland, but across northern Europe.But their interests stayed local."James excavated the now famous Roman fort of Trimontium at Newstead, and helped the Galashiels Ramblers Club excavate the mysterious site of Torwoodlee Broch."Just over  years later the Curle brothers influence on Scottish archaeology is still strong, and its only fitting that following in their footsteps the Trimontium Trust, along with the German Archaeological Institute, have provided exciting new insights into both Trimontium and Torwoodlee Broch using cutting edge geophysical techniques."This is no doubt the beginnings of a new revolution in our understanding of the Borders rich archaeological heritage that will still be celebrated  years from now."

title: adam-has-some-food-for-thought-for-borders-communities
story: A PEEBLES gardener is urging Borderers to follow his lead and set up more Food Communities in the area.Adam Skelton recently transformed land behind the townrsquos old courthouse into a public garden, where locals can grow their own produce.And now he wants to see more green-fingered people getting stuck in across the region. The -year-old told us: ldquoI was first introduced to gardening by my parents who were growing all sorts of fruit and vegetables whilst I was at school.ldquoI remember really enjoying picking fresh fruit in the garden. And I loved eating my mumrsquos crumbles, cakes and pies that she made with them.ldquoThe food I grew up eating was amazing ndash served after lots of preparation, and usually using fresh home-grown ingredients. Food and community are two of the most fundamental things to me.ldquoAnd theyrsquore two things that we should be doing so much better. Food Communities is essentially about communities coming together to produce their own food. My aim is to inspire collaboration. If lots of people get involved we can be enjoying the freshest, tastiest, healthiest, most eco-friendly, truly local food and saving lots of money.Adam has helped to transform a number gardens as part of the Food Communities scheme ndash a social enterprise run by volunteers.He added: ldquoItrsquos relatively easy to begin growing for yourself ndash from the tiniest garden to someone who has a spare patch of land and would just like a helping hand to turn it into a burgeoning community garden.ldquoItrsquos a common misconception that growing your own food is too much work and takes too much time it actually doesnrsquot need much of either ndash as long as you keep going with it regularly, and share the workload.ldquoFood Communities spotlights the endless amazing things going on every day in our communities and provides a  for neighbours, young and old, to work together with a common purpose. Because we pay no rent or wages and do and acquire everything for free, we have a resilient long-term plan and a template that we aim to offer to local communities all across Scotland.A Facebook group has been set up to offer advice to people thinking about getting involved and monthly meet-ups also take place.Adam added: ldquoWe usually have an expert guest speaker talking to us about food, community and environment related topics. Group members also regularly swap and share food, tools, materials, resources, seeds, plants, knowledge, and skills.For more information, visit: www.facebook communitiesfood

title: aussies-say-good-on-ya-to-melrosian-honesty
story: MELROSE isnrsquot just the best place to live in Scotland.It is also the most honest, according to two Australian tourists.The couple from Down Under were sampling the historical delights of the town recently.But Afton Johnston and her husbandrsquos dream trip turned into a nightmare when they left their camera, full of holiday memories, in Market Square.The couple had driven almost  miles north before realising.But, thanks to staff at a Melrose cafe, the Melbourne pair can enjoy leafing through their snaps once again.Afton told the Border : ldquoWe discovered later that I had left my camera on a seat in the square.ldquoAfter leaving the square I went shopping in Boots the chemist. And from Melrose we drove to Falkirk, where I discovered my camera containing a monthrsquos holiday photos was missing.ldquoAt the Falkirk Wheel Visitor Centre they made some calls for me. The chemist suggested that we ring the cafe in front of the seat. They rang Rhymers Fayre and the gentleman there went out into the street to check.ldquoMy camera was still on the seat after two hours, we drove to Melrose and collected it. Thank you to the helpful Melrose folk.The town was named the best place to live in Scotland, by the Sunday Times back in March.

title: scottish-wildcats-release-planned-for-scottish-borders
story: A CONSERVATION group has unveiled plans to reintroduce the Scottish wildcat into the Borders.The move by Wildcat Haven comes as proposals to release six lynx into Kielder are currently being considered by the UK Government.It is widely accepted that Scottish wildcat numbers have been dwindling across their native Highlands for many years.And Wildcat Haven has been spearheading fieldwork over the last decade to end the decline.This week the group announced its latest plans - to release the iconic felines along the Scotland-England border.Dr Paul ODonoghue, chief scientic advisor with Wildcat Haven, told us: "The British ecology needs a wildcat in it and wildcats fit in perfectly, helping to control species like rabbit and actively avoiding conflict with humans.ldquoThe Highlands cant afford to lose any Scottish wildcats so well be looking to healthy, wild-living European populations, and using them to re-establish a British wildcat population on both sides of the Scottish-English border.The proposals initially focus on the Galloway area with the reintroduced cats being encouraged to spread into the Scottish Borders as well as Cumbria and Northumberland.If the plans are successful it would be the first time wildcats have been present in England for over  years.Dr ODonoghue added: ldquoWeve seen that wildcats can really thrive in man-made forests, and an important part of our research is understanding how we can create a sustainable population in this environment."The Galloway-Northumberland border region is often overlooked but this is one of the most well connected and erse habitats in the UK, and certainly rivals the Highlands for bioersity potential."The wildcat is the UKs most endangered animal, and its probably the most charismatic and iconic species that has managed to cling on here against all odds theyre incredible survivors and I have no doubt they will thrive in the forests of the Southern Uplands and Northern England."The plan already has considerable landowner support coming from Gresham House Forestry, one of the largest owners of forestry in the UK and the Galloway region.Jason Sinden, Director of Forestry, said: "Gresham House manages almost , acres of forestry assets in the border region."These forests are managed to produce a sustainable supply of timber and this helps to create almost ideal habitats for a range of native woodland specialists, such a red squirrels, badgers and roe deer."The forests are now being re-colonised by pine-martens and we hope that the habitat can also be suitable for the wildcat, which is such an important component of forest eco-systems."We will be working with Wildcat Haven to identy appropriate sites for release and monitoring.

title: council-agrees-185m-plan-to-build-1000-affordable-homes
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has agreed a five year affordable housing plan which could see over , homes built by .Local authorities are required to submit affordable housing plans to the Scottish Government each year, which itself has a target of building , new homes.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive body on Tuesday, councillors were asked to give their approval to the plans by Cathie Fancy, the local authorityrsquos housing strategy and services manager.She told councillors: ldquoItrsquos really pertinent here, that over the last ten housing strategy submissions to the government, wersquove delivered about  new affordable homes, but over the next five years wersquore actually hoping to provide more than that.ldquoThis just shows you the extent of the ambition in what wersquore trying to do and and everyone is playing their part.The homes will represent nearly poundm of investment over a five year period, which will be funded by grants from the Scottish Government, private borrowing from housing associations and money raised by Scottish Borders Councilrsquos second homes tax.Councillor Mark Rowley, the local authorityrsquos executive member for business and economic development, said: ldquoConsidering we donrsquot hold housing stock ourselves, itrsquos a great tribute to Cathy that housing has been such a priority for this council, and I know that the many people living in wonderful homes across the Scottish Borders will be very grateful to her.,params: .pushldquoThese figures are quite incredible. In rough terms, wersquore talking about an investment here of around poundm between ious sources, including ourselves, our partners and government.ldquoA lot has been raised by quite spirited borrowing from our registered social landlord partners who, like the council, are being very ambitious about housing in the Scottish Borders.ldquoIf we can deliver an extra , good, affordable, warm homes then that is to be commended.ldquoThe overall message here is incredibly positive, itrsquos talking about building homes across the region and building them in a signicant quantity.Kelso councillor Simon Mountford also welcomed the report, heaping praise on the environmentally friendly plans for energy-efficient housing: ldquoOne thing I would like to highlight from the presentation is the plan from Eildon Housing Association to build a number of passive houses.ldquoThey will dramatically reduce the cost of heating for the tenants of those housing. When we consider that fuel poverty is one of those things that we as a council very much want to tackle then this is a step in the right direction.ldquoI personally hope that this will be a switch to building passive houses as standard throughout the Borders.Speaking after the meeting, Mid Berwickshire councillor Mr Rowley added: ldquoAs a council we are determined to support the delivery of much-needed affordable homes across the area.ldquoThis helps young people stay and work in the area, have families and put down roots here. That has a signicant, long term positive impact on our local economy.ldquoMore than , affordable homes would go a long way to meeting housing needs in our communities over the next five years and would also help support the local construction sector, providing a further boost to the economy.ldquoIt is an ambitious plan and there are certainly some challenges, from land supply to funding, but we continue to work very closely with a range of partners, including registered social landlords and the Scottish Government, to maximise opportunities to deliver more affordable homes.

title: unemployment-soars-in-the-scottish-borders
story: UNEMPLOYMENT in the Borders has soared by almost  per cent from last year.Figures released by the Department for Work and Pensions show a surge of benefits claimants in the past  months from  last September to a current figure of .The unemployment increase is across all age demographics, with a -person riserecorded in -to- year-olds.Although the year-on-year increase of  percent is disappointing, staff at local Jobcentres highlighted a long-term trend which has seen  percent reduction in claimants across the Borders since .Staff at Galashiels Jobcentre are also launching several courses in a bid to help more people back into work.Customer Services Leader Stephen Glen told us: "We are currently running a Construction SBWA for customers in Galashiels Jobcentre Plus for our unemployed customers keen to work in the Construction Industry."It will provide the  participants with an opportunity to gain the necessary certication to work in construction."Funding has been applied for to run two -plus courses in the Gala area aimed at supporting our longer term unemployed customers aged  and over."These courses will be ready to start once a suitable provider in the area has been sourced."

title: st-boswells-store-in-the-running-to-become-britains-best-small-shop
story: A COMBINED bookshop, cafeacute, deli and homeware shop in St Boswells is in the running to become Britainrsquos Best Small Shop of .The Mainstreet Trading Company, which is celebrating its tenth anniversary this year, is one of  independent retailers from across the country named on the prestigious shortlist.Over the years, innovations introduced by the business include the lsquoA Year of Booksrsquo subscription service, Book Burrows for children and the Love Your Indie book loyalty card.Rosamund de la Hey, co-owner of Mainstreet, told us: "We are always looking for ways to engage with the local community."Whether thatrsquos through our Bookshop Van, which aims to ensure every child in the Borders meets an author through Mainstreet during their school le through our Summer Reading Diary where children review up to six books with the winners receiving their height in books or our noticeboard to publicise local arts events.The Best Small Shops competition, which is managed by the Independent Retailers Confederation sponsored by loyalty app booost, celebrates the commitment and creativity of independent retailers on the UKrsquos High Streets and the central role they play in their local communities.Mark Walmsley, chairman of the Independent Retailers Confederation, added: "Despite all of the bad headlines and the high-profile closures of larger stores, we firmly believe that specialist independent retailers can thrive in this climate by delivering a truly unique retail experience.ldquoThe Best Small Shops competition enables us celebrate this unique industry, the passion, service, flexibility and knowledge of independent shop owners offer and show customers what makes independent retailers so special.The winner of Britainrsquos Best Small Shop will be announced at an event at the Houses of Parliament on November .

title: great-adventurers-brought-to-book-by-jo
story: OVER the past few years, Royal Scottish Geographical Society writer-in-residence Jo Woolf has immersed herself in the Societyrsquos archives.So much so, that last year she published her debut book The Great Horizon, which features  exceptional adventure stories from the last  years - and each from an inidual connected to the Society.From missionaries and mavericks to visionaries and voyagers, the explorers included in Jorsquos book have ventured into unknown regions of the globe ndash across ice, desert, and rainforest, over uncharted waters, and into the unfathomed depths of the ocean.Some are famous historical characters, such as Sir Ernest Shackleton, Roald Amundson, Sir Edmund Hilary and Neil Armstrong.But there is also an intriguing collection of additional names such as Isobel Wylie Hutchison, Hubert Wilkins, Marion Newbigin and Mildred Cable that are less well known that Jo skilfully shines a light on.As part of the RSGS Inspiring People talks programme, Jo will be bringing to le some of these characters and their stories in a richly illustrated presentation and QA session entitled Beyond the Horizon.The event will take place at .pm on Tuesday October in Galashiels.Speaking about her upcoming talk, Jo Woolf said: "I have been repeatedly amazed, moved, entertained, and uplted by these remarkable stories."The definition of exploration may have been re-shaped somewhat over the decades, but the courage and enduring spirit of explorers is still the same. "Having spent the last few years digging around in the archives of the RSGS, I want to share some of these extraordinary tales with you, and tell you how I came to write The Great Horizon.Jorsquos talk will take place on Tuesday at .pm at the Scottish Borders Campus, Nether Road, Galashiels, TD HE.Ticketswill be available on the door or online via Eventbrite until noon the day before.

title: home-bargains-submits-plans-for-hawick-homebase-site
story: THE Homebase store in Hawick could be given a new lease of le as a rival retailer has submitted plans for the site to Scottish Borders Council.The parent company of discount retail giant Home Bargains, TJ Morris, has put in an application to the local authorityrsquos planning department to allow food retailing on the premises.The Liverpool-headquartered firm has stores at  locations and currently employs around , staff throughout the UK.It also opened up a new poundm store in Galashiels in the summer, providing dozens of new jobs in a ,sq ft unit in Stirling Street.Homebase, on the other hand, announced in August that it was closing  of its stores, putting , staff out of work, as part of a national shake-up designed to revive its fortunes.That includes its store at Galalaw Retail Park in Hawick at the cost of  jobs.Speaking at the time the closure was announced, Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk MP John Lamont said: ldquoThis is hugely disappointing news for staff, their families and Hawick itself.ldquoJust when it seems that a recovery is on the horizon for the town, a blow like this is announced.ldquoHomebase have promised to relocate staff where possible. However, with the next nearest stores being in Carlisle or Berwick, this isnrsquot going to be suitable for most.The application from TJ Morris, submitted by Glasgow-based planning consultancy Iceni Projects, would see  per cent of the ,sq m site given over to food retailing, although the company is refusing to comment on the specics of the proposal.Hawick and Denholm councillor Stuart Marshall has welcomed the news, saying: ldquoI think itrsquos very encouraging that someone has come along so quickly.ldquoI know the company were expressing great interest, and Irsquom sure many people will be pleased by this news.The application might provide similar jobs at the site, but the presence of another out-of-town retailer will do little to revitalise the high street of a town which has been in dramatic decline over the last decade.A recent report put to Scottish Borders Council showed that footfall in the town centre has more than halved since , and there are now  retail units standing vacant.

title: light-therapy-arrives-at-bgh-via-the-fairways
story: FAIRYWAY-hitting golfers are helping to bring some light relief to Borders General Hospital.Dozens of big-hitters teed up at the Roxburghe Golf Course for the inaugural Friends of the BGH tournament, organised by Nigel Brown.Coming out on top of the leaderboard was the Middlemiss Embroidery Ltd team.But, undoubtedly, the overall winner is the hospitals dermatology department which will benefit from a new pound, PUVA light therapy machine - after more than pound, was raised for the pot during the tournament.James Marjoribanks from Friends of the BGH told us: "The PUVA Light Therapy machine, among other uses, can be used to treat skin cancer."We are the only health board in Scotland not to have one and Border patients who require this treatment have to travel up to Edinburgh at the moment, so we are really grateful to all the teams that took part, the sponsors, Roxburghe Golf Club and, especially Nigel Brown for organising this event.If anyone is interested in raising additional money for the Friends of the BGH, contact James at jym@hoggandthorburn.

title: matt-leaves-behind-the-whale-to-play-in-the-borders
story: FOUNDING member of Noah and the Whale, Matt Owens, is set to play in the Borders next month.And tickets are freeordered in advance.Noah and the Whale were among the pioneers of the indi-folk sound in the noughties along with the likes of Mumford and Sons and Vampire Weekend.Singles such as LIFEGOESON and  Years Time propelled them into the charts and onto the main stage at festivals across the world.After coming to prominence more than a decade ago as part of the of Noah and the Whale, Matt also went on to front the equally impressive Little Mammoths.And now, after penning a string of hits along the way, he is about to tour with his debut solo album Whiskey and Orchids, which he has been working on with Thea Gilmore, Michael Blair, Robert Vincentand Carleigh Aitkens.Matt will be joined at the Memorial Hall in Innerleithen by Nigel Stonier.Nigel is a producer, multi-instrumentalist and singer songwriter co-writer and since the s he has worked with a range of artists including Thea Gilmore, The Waterboys, Joan Baez, Martha Wainwright and Fairport Convention.Between  and  he has produced a total - for ious artistes - of  tracks playlisted on BBC Radio  and BBC Radio  Music.Since scoring a publishing contract when aged  Nigel has been an active and busy musician, initially attracting national radio attention with the band Northern Sky then setting his stall out as a producer collaborator.Ticketsfor the Matt Owens and Nigel Stonier concert in Innerleithen are free by registering in advance at www.onthebrinck events matt-owens-noah-and-the-whale-little-mammothsDoors open on Saturday, November  at pm.

title: tickets-now-on-sale-for-galashiels-remembrance-concert
story: AHEAD Of this years centenary of Armistice a special Remembrance Concertis being staged in Galashiels.Musicians, singers and poets will take to the Volunteer Hall stage to pay tribute to the sacrice made by so many in the four years of war up to .The show is part of the Gala Remembers  project which aims to highlight the towns war effort.And to create a respectful commemoration for all the  sons of Galashiels who didnt come home.Gordon Keddie is the organiser of the concert.He said: ldquoI discussed this idea with Energise Galashiels Trust and we agreed it was important to hold this event on the th anniversary of the ending of the First World War to give a proper tribute to the  men from Galashiels who lost their lives during the conflict.Among those to perform on the evening are Galashiels Ex-Service Pipe Band and the Town Band.Langlee Community Choir, One Acchord Choir, Alastair Waddell and Lorraine Kemp will also take to the stage.And there will be poetry by Galashiels Academy pupil Sophie MacDonald.Bill White, Chair of Gala Remembers  added: ldquoMusic halls were hugely popular during World War I and it is fitting we will have our own concert as part of Gala Remembers .ldquoThere is some great local talent set to perform on and we would encourage Borderers and visitors from further afield to come along to support them on this poignant and important weekend.The concert will take place on Friday, November  from .pm.Ticketsfor the show, priced at pound and include a souvenir programme, are on sale daily between pm and pm from the British Legion Club in Park Street, Galashiels.More information on Gala Remembers  is available at www.energisegalashiels gala-remembers-Notes to EditorsPhoto credit. title: belfasts-andy-set-to-rave-on-in-the-borders
story: ANDY White, Belfast born and Belfast bred, first picked up a guitar when he was .It was blocking up the hallway, so he started strumming it in a beatnik basement belonging to a big bloke called Bobby.So started the  press release for Andyrsquos debut album, reissued by Vinyl  on October .The eighties folk revival led by The Pogues, The Waterboys and Hothouse Flowers cut an authentic, soulful swathe through the music culture of the MTV generation.On Rave On, Andyrsquos voice and lyrics told the story of a boy growing up in the political and social chaos of Northern Ireland and making his way to Thatcherrsquos Britain with an acoustic guitar and a suitcase full of poetry books, Clash cassettes and Bob Dylan albums.Originally recorded in a field in County Antrim, this yearrsquos reissue is a limited edition in white g vinyl with a gatefold sleeve.It still sounds fresh, raw and urgent today and is complemented by latest album The Guilty  The Innocent, Andyrsquos reaction tothe current news cycle.Grenfell, Trump, Corbyn, equality and justice are its themes.The six minute title track stunned audiences on his UK tour last year.Along the line connecting these two albums, Andy has collaborated with the likes of Tim Finn and Liam O Maonlai , written with Peter Gabriel, recorded with Sinead OrsquoConnor and toured with Van Morrison.But Andyrsquos voice, trademark lyrical wit and the magic he can conjure up with musicians in a studio remains a constant.Along with a stellar career in music hersquos always kept a firm grip on the ldquohave guitar, will travel folksinger ethos on display in the back of a Beetle, one West London afternoon in .Andy will be touring across the UK this winter - including a date in the Borders.He will play at the Heart Of Hawick on Monday, December .Ticketsare avialable from  .

title: a-fairtrade-coffee-morning-for-melrose
story: MELROSE Rotarians have teamed up with the local Fairtrade Group to host a special coffee morning.Held later this month, the event will serve up Fairtrade tea, coffee and traybakes.And there will also be a chance to buy Christmas gts, decorations and a range of books to support the charity Kabuki UK.Peter Carter from the Rotary Club said: "As a key local charity, we feel it is important to recognise that Melrose is a Fairtrade Town. By making our coffee morning a Fairtrade event, not only are we raising funds for our own local work but we are also supporting farmers and growers in developing countries. Last year we welcomed over  people to our coffee morning and provided an excellent opportunity to socialise and take a break from Saturday morning shopping."The event is also being supported by the local Co-op store.The Fairtrade Group achieved Fairtrade Town status for Melrose in  and will be seeking to renew that position when members apply to the Fairtrade Foundation later this month.David Potts from the group added: "We have built a great partnership with the local Rotarians over the past two years and this will benefit us when we are called to show that the work of our group has grown and developed since our last renewal application.The coffee morning is being held at the Corn Exchange, on Saturday, October  from am until noon. Entry is free with tea, coffee and cake at pound.

title: chance-to-find-out-more-about-solar
story: BORDERERS will be able to find out more about solar renewable energy next week.Hosted by Change Works, a free information evening will be held in the Burgh Hall on Thursday for locals, businesses and community groups.From .pm, attendees will have an opportunity to chat to local specialist installers before hearing from Home Energy Scotland experts about the benefits of solar , the costs and savings involved and the free, impartial support which is available.A Resource Efficient Scotland advisor will also be on hand to provide advice and support to local Tweeddale businesses.Donna Marshall, Change Works in Peebles project manager told us: "This is an ideal event for any local householder, business or community group who has considered installing solar  or renewables and needs further advice to help make a decision."Solar photo voltaics can be a great way to cut your electricity bills."Sunlight is free, so once youve paid for the initial installation, your electricity costs can be reduced."Change Works in Peebles is here to help and support the local community to find out more about generating solar renewable energy."You can book your free place online at bit.ly SolarTweeddale pop into the Change Works in Peebles hub email peebles@changeworks.org.uk or call  .

title: funding-boost-is-a-path-to-success-on-the-eildons
story: PATHS on the Eildon Hills are set for improvement following a six-figure cash boost.The pound, funding, secured by Scottish Borders Council, will be used to improve areas of erosion on more than km of upland paths in the popular National Scenic Area.Councillor Mark Rowley, Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive member for business and economic development, said: ldquoThe walks in the Eildons are extremely popular, not only with local people but also with visitors, as the paths include the well-known, long-distance route St Cuthbertrsquos Way.ldquoIt is estimated that around  walkers a week use these paths and it is vital to ensure that the experience for visitors is positive, due the impact on the local visitor economy, but also that the hills themselves and the paths are protected for future generations of Borderers and visitors to enjoy.The funding has been secured from the Rural Tourism Infrastructure Fund, administered by VisitScotland.Announced last year by the Scottish Government, the fund aims to provide sustainable infrastructure projects that focus on improving visitor experience and enable more visitors to enjoy Scotlandrsquos rural communities.It was set up to address the pressure on infrastructure and negative impacts on local communities caused by the increasing popularity of Scotlandrsquos outstanding scenic areas.VisitScotland regional leadership director, Paula Ward, said: ldquoDue to the continued success of tourism it is crucial that we address those pinch points already identied and future-proof those areas where demand is growing.ldquoI am delighted that the Eildon Hills project will receive funding from the Scottish Government Rural Tourism Infrastructure Fund to help enhance and safeguard this iconic part of the Scottish Borders scenery for future visitors and the local community.ldquoWith its proximity to the Borders Railway, it is popular with local walkers as well as those from further afield wishing to discover one of the best walks in the UK, and experience the fantastic scenery on offer at the top.ldquoVisitScotland, along with other agencies and industry partners, needs to encourage the tourism industry to provide world class service, facilities, events and attractions to keep up with ever-changing consumer demands and ensure visitors continue to have memorable experiences.The erosion of parts of the path network in the Eildons has been caused by ious factors, including weather, volume of use, soil type and topography.The councilrsquos Ranger Service manages maintenance on the promoted path routes over the hills, and over the past  years, has carried out a range of works on lower reaches of the paths.This latest project, to be carried out next year, will involve more intense upland path works.The Eildon Hills are owned by Buccleuch Estates. Edward Morris, estate manager at Buccleuchrsquos Borders Estate, said: ldquoAccess to the Eildon Hills is hugely valued by those who live in the region as well as visitors from across the country.ldquoIt is excellent news that the well-trekked path network is to be upgraded and this will only enhance the enjoyment of current enthusiasts and encourage new walkers to go out and enjoy this beautul landscape.

title: contestants-came-saw-and-conkered
story: THERE were some tough nuts to crack at the annual Scottish Conker Championships at the weekend.Competitors from all over the UK gathered on the Tweed Green in Peebles on Saturday ndash in a bid to take home one of the coveted trophies.And after taking part in a string of events, this yearrsquos winner was lsquoEl Conkistadorrsquo, from Conkistan, who defeated Norfolkrsquos Tim Frost in the final.Maurice Hurrell from Fe won the rogue category Tristan Van claimed the youth - trophy while Phoenix Taylor prevailed in the seven- age group.The event is organised each year by the Borders Forest Trust. And the organisation is delighted with how the day went.Anna Craigen, the grouprsquos community and education officer, told us: ldquoIt was a really good day by all accounts, everyone enjoyed it and we saw some new champions. We were very pleased for El Conkistador, who won the adult section, as he has been a regular competitor at the event for many years.ldquoWe were also very pleased with the turnout and luckily the weather held out for us ndash evenit did get a little bit chilly later on in the day.ldquoThere were four contestants taking part in the youth section,  in the adult section and  children taking part in the junior section, which was great.ldquoIt was also great to welcome many competitors from around Britain. We had some from Fe, and one contestant was from Norfolk, Tim Frost, who reached the final ndash that was the furthest distance travelled.
